output: Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. President, Madam Vice-President, the Commission gives the impression of acting like a distracted student rushing to recover lost time before submitting their examination paper.
Certainly, the social package exists, but it is incomplete and can only be considered as a step towards the Commission taking social issues into account.

The President of the Commission failed to grasp the warning issued by citizens in France, the Netherlands, and Ireland—a warning that would unfortunately have been mirrored elsewhere had a popular vote taken place.
These elections serve as a corrective measure.
If Europeans want more Europe, it is to build a societal project and not merely to adopt even more technical directives.
Regulation of the internal market is certainly necessary, but it is not, by any means, the essential element.
The 2009 program, like its predecessors, will miss the mark.
Citizens do not expect the commission to merely supplement, nor even to simplify legislation.
They await the Commission—that it rise to the task assigned to it by the treaties, the engine, the wellspring of ideas for the Union.
It is not enough for that its president be wise and silent, standing at attention behind the President of the Council.
We expect the Commission to act as a key player in the reflection on the nature of the societal project we need.
But what is the societal vision underpinning this program?
The 2009 program does not contain serious errors, but it is not the program our fellow citizens need.
Mr. President, it will be up to the new College to take responsibility.
I only hope that he will be less deaf to the calls of the people than the current one.
Thank you, Mr. President.

from the high-level conference on Georgia that had been proposed by the French presidency and how the current Union presidency intends to defend Georgia’s territorial integrity, even as one country recognizes two separatist regions, Abkhazia and South Ossetia.
But it is a shame that Mr. Barroso is not here because in his speech, he was not convincing, perhaps because he himself is not convinced by the proposals he has put forward to us.
I believe that the financial and economic situation is far more serious than he described to us.
And even today, I believe those who follow the Internet see very well that the stock markets continue to collapse despite interventions.

For me, it represents the collapse of the current system, a system entirely obsolete, the system that led to bankruptcy, that led a land to be totally exploited and stifled by greenhouse gas emissions, that led to underdevelopment in the Global South and that led to underdevelopment in our cities.
I thank the President, the Commissioner. The current financial crisis clearly demonstrates that when the problem is global, a global action is required.
And this is especially true in the field of agriculture or in the food industry.
That is why, in particular, the World Trade Organization was created, on which we agree, and which seeks to establish globalized rules.

It so happens that it doesn’t work quite as we would like, because we are confronted with the following problem. We must entrust two things: free trade, which is essential and on which everyone agrees, but protections, which are equally necessary.
And protections for national economies or agricultures, that does not mean protectionism.
To that end, the path we have taken for 60 years, since the GATT, has been an unbalanced one, moving towards the reduction of tariffs with the ultimate goal of their elimination.
It so happens that technically, the reduction of customs duties
It is difficult. The proof is a whole series of mathematical formulas, the South Korean formula, the European formula, or the most well-known formula, the Swiss formula.
It doesn't really work because a product is not unitary.
It is composed of numerous elements with rules of very different origins, and technically reducing customs duties is not as simple as one might think.
We are therefore in a technical impasse, and politically, we are attempting to negotiate our way out of it.

Alternatively, it so happens that technologically, scientists have invented a new customs technology, the technology of deductible duties, deductible by the exporter against the importing state’s savings.
Concretely, this deductible customs duty transforms into a customs credit equal to the amount of the customs duty borne by the exporter in the importing country.
This customs credit has three characteristics: it is refundable, negotiable, and eligible for bonus.
It is refundable at the moment when the exporter purchases from the importer; he can deduct the customs duty he has borne.
It is negotiable because if the exporting company that has borne 100 in customs duties has nothing to purchase from the importer, it negotiates its duty credit on the stock market or with a bank.
And it is eligible for bonus if we wish to assist developing countries, the importer, by offering a credit amount exceeding the duty amount.
With this technique, we create an international currency of exchange whose monetary mass equals the amount of existing customs duties.
For example, the European Union would offer 13 billion euros in international currency within the commercial sphere.

Thank you, Mr. President. The Russo-Georgian conflict and the financial crisis provided the European Union with the opportunity to assert itself on the world stage as a fully-fledged and leading political actor.
Thanks to your determination, Mr. President of the Council, Europe has managed to unite and find coordinated, effective, and rapid responses.
Faced with crises, Europe demonstrates its existence and its added value.
In matters of immigration, for example, the every man for himself approach was no longer in vogue.
The European Council's adoption of the pact on immigration and asylum, initiated by the French presidency, represents a significant step forward.
Regarding the fight against climate change, Europe must set concrete objectives and lead the way for its global partners.

You have already expressed yourself on this matter, Mr. President of the Council, but we wish this agreement to be as balanced as possible, as it must take into account the economic situation of our countries, which is currently very destabilized.
but also raise the question of the type of development we will choose for the future.
To meet the challenges that lie ahead, the European Union needs the Treaty of Lisbon more than ever.
We understand the concerns of our Irish friends, but the status quo is not an option.
Ireland must propose a solution at the December European Council. Many of us are calling for it.
In recent weeks, we have observed with pride a strong, united Europe in the face of adversity, resolute with its partners, and listened to on the international stage.
We wish this new European mindset to become the norm and to endure.
The Treaty of Lisbon is the best solution available to us for achieving that goal.

Thank you, Madam President. Minister, I was in Tbilisi when President Sarkozy came to negotiate the peace plan. And of course, I pay tribute to him for having acted swiftly and for knowing how to stop that war.
But this war is, in a way, our failure. We were hesitant for 14 years. We silently witnessed the escalation of provocations in the separatist regions.

And this war, indeed, has awakened Europe by presenting it with its responsibilities. But the fire continues to smolder in the Caucasus. And we must do everything in our power to definitively resolve the frozen conflicts for the security of all of Europe.
And I am also aware, Minister, of the divisions among European countries regarding Georgia’s accession to NATO. And personally, I am opposed.
And I will make you a proposition. I will ask the European Union to propose the status of neutrality for these Caucasian countries.
Only the status of neutrality can appease tensions with Russia and definitively prevent this sub-region from new conflicts.
This status will ensure the security of these young democracies and contribute to our own security.
Mr. Prime Minister, these past three days have marked European Development Days, where the food crisis affecting the poorest countries has been extensively discussed and
All interventions emphasized the absolute necessity for developing countries to develop their own agriculture by optimally utilizing their land and natural resources.

Incidentally, the lyrical pronouncements of those who yesterday and still today call for a reduction in state intervention and public spending, for liberalization in all directions, for privatization, for relegating agriculture to the status of...
this quasi-prehistoric activity, this volte-face therefore in favor of massive public investment in agricultural production and food sovereignty, all of it with something both comical and scandalous.
The future of agriculture in developing countries has a direct relationship with the debate we are having today.

I regret to say that I do not feel this health check of the CAP, initiated before the peak of the hunger riots and the disastrous market disturbances, takes into account the situation of Southern farmers and draws all the consequences of the serious risks we are now facing, ecological, social, economic, and financial.

I therefore deeply regret that the strong relationship between farmers in the North and the South is so little addressed, both in the Commission’s proposals and in the Parliament’s report. The questioning of the promised billion euros demonstrates how much further there is to go.
Thank you, Mr. President. The report we will vote on tomorrow marks the culmination of a year of work and negotiations dedicated to the future of the common agricultural policy and our farmers.
Indeed, it was last November 20th that Mrs. Fischer-Bowle presented her proposals regarding the health assessment.
Following the tables report by Lutz Goebbels, here comes the Capula-Santo report on the Commission's proposal.
We must congratulate our two colleagues for their excellent work.
The European Parliament’s Committee on Agriculture managed to remain steadfast in its response to the initial proposals from the Commission, which we deemed far too liberal.
I will remain vigilant regarding the dairy sector and, in particular, the measures preceding the abolition of quotas.

I am thinking in particular of mountain milk producers who must not be the forgotten stepchildren of this reform, and it will be essential to ensure that they are not left aside, as they will need to be supported more than others.
I do not wish to play the Cassandra, but how can one imagine the French dairy industry consolidated within a single region?
Therefore, I welcome the proposal to establish a milk fund with benevolence, as well as the proposal to evaluate, starting in 2010, the increase in milk quotas based on market developments.

The calculation of the progressive modulation made by the Agriculture Commission appears to me to be fair. It would allow us to strengthen the development of territories, rural areas, and to sustainably preserve biodiversity.
I also welcome the clarification of eco-conditionality, the implementation of which had previously been a genuine challenge for farmers.

I also wish that we retain the tobacco fund amount, which allows us to maintain small farms in Europe, as well as a significant workforce in a region where nothing else is exploitable and which enables us to avoid imported products.
Finally, Minister, we greatly appreciated your commitment throughout these negotiations.
You have demonstrated considerable patience and determination, and you have not spared your time, without falsehood.
It was a genuine pleasure to work alongside you.
You have been exceptionally effective working with us.
I know that we can count on you.
First, thank you for the work completed and the conclusions and orientations proposed by the health assessment of the CAP, as detailed in Mr. Caboulos-Santos’s report.
Agriculture is indeed an economic sector that cannot respond to simple market signals.
Its activity has impacts, of course, on food self-sufficiency, but also, as we experience too often, on territories and employment.
The elimination of market instruments would be a serious blow to our agriculture.

Decoupling, for example, presents a genuine challenge for certain livestock territories, particularly those raising beef cattle and sheep, and I was pleased to hear Ms. Fischer-Boll address this issue earlier.
Furthermore, it is clear that the strict adherence to historical references would severely impede any possibility of reform.
However, I still believe that the question of the second pillar of the CAP is an essential one because rural areas need to rely on agricultural activity to develop employment in rural communities.
And therefore, it is necessary to reflect on this issue of the second foot, without, of course, amputating the first.
Given that Minister Jouyens is leaving us, I believe this Parliament should thank him.
He was one of the most diligent ministers we have known.
I wish them good luck.

Madam President, if I voted in favor of the Perriche report concerning the integration of the OCM20 into the former Munich system, it was with a heavy heart, because I believe that this single CMO is neither a simplification nor does it increase transparency.
It will make life more complicated for winegrowers, for the entire wine industry.
Last night, the commissioner attempted to reassure us.
I hope that the Commission will keep its word and that, above all, the profession will continue to be adequately represented on the advisory committee, as has been the case since the first CMO 20.
Sir
Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, our group enthusiastically supports the Small Business Act presented to us by the Commission last June.

Certainly, since the 2000s, initiatives have been undertaken targeting SMEs, and I am particularly thinking of our colleague Dominique Blasto’s excellent work on the SME charter. Initiatives that were appreciated, but deemed insufficient because they often remained merely aspirational.
Today, we must go further.
The severe economic crisis that our countries are experiencing, and the consequences of which are particularly concerning for SMEs, need no further prompting.
In this regard, the Small Business Act aligns with a novel, decidedly proactive approach.
In a few weeks, we will examine Ms. Herzog’s report on Commission communication. But today, through the submission of this oral question, we wished to engage the Council.
Dear Minister, we have taken note with interest of the conclusions adopted yesterday by the Competitiveness Council and would like to know whether the European Council, as of December 11th and 12th,

will effectively convey its conclusions and provide a strong impetus to ensure that the overarching principle of “think small first” is rapidly transposed into the regulatory framework of the Member States.
We wish for the Council to commit to the principle of the action plan annexed with concrete measures.
In this regard, and within the limited time afforded to me, I will emphasize three areas where we require binding impetus.
impact studies that should be systematic and the regular monitoring, with the European Parliament’s oversight of the implementation status of the Small Business Act in the Member States,
access to the public market
The code of good conduct has no binding force. We must, together, be more imaginative, more inventive, and propose concrete, adapted measures that genuinely open markets to SMEs.
Finally, access to financing, more essential than ever in the current context.
Your proposals are sound, Minister. They must also incorporate support for supply.
There is an urgent need.
Thank you for confirming the Council’s willingness.
Mr. President, Minister, Commissioner, we all know that SMEs are the backbone of the European Union, employing over 70% of the European Union's workforce and representing 99% of European businesses.

But as has already been said, these millions of small and medium-sized enterprises are now concerned and threatened by the financial crisis because it erodes household purchasing power and confidence, and impacts order books.

It is therefore the cash flow of SMEs that is at risk, and it is consequently necessary to ensure their activities are supported by guaranteeing that banks provide effective access to the financing required for the continuity of their operations.
This is the crux of the conclusions of the Competitiveness Council of December 1st, which Mr. the Minister discussed, and of the recovery plan approved by the European Finance Ministers.
Making the needs of SMEs a permanent political priority of the Union is essential. And I wanted to commend the Small Business Act for Europe action plan.
It does, in effect, translate the desire to ensure the effective application of the guiding principle, to give priority to small businesses first, that is, European SMEs.
However, as the Commissioner has said, and as we all say, the Council must genuinely engage with the other European institutions.

European. For this principle to be rendered effective now, it is necessary to move beyond the scope of the declaration; it is necessary to proceed to its implementation in all European policies and programmes.
However, we can state that this action plan represents a genuine response to the urgency of the situation.
And I wished to acknowledge, Minister, the proactive approach of the French presidency of the Union, which has enabled swift translation of intentions into action.

Madam President, in office, Mr. Commissioner, I lend my full support to the rapporteur who defends the position that was ours in the first reading, a position rejected by the governments of the Member States.
It was urgent to align our custody legislation with the case law of the Court of Justice. This has now been accomplished.
The Cercas report provides balanced and protective responses for employees.
all custody time is counted as working time.
Compensatory rest follows immediately after the service period.
It is a matter of common sense to guarantee decent working conditions, particularly for medical professions.
But the reform of the working time directive also gives us the opportunity to advance our European social law by eliminating the individual opt-out.
The Cercas report seizes this opportunity and proposes a gradual elimination of any possibility of derogating from the legal maximum working time.
One must face reality.
It is a jest to suggest that an employee finds themselves in a position of equality with their employer and can refuse what is offered to them.
Dear colleagues, we must clearly demonstrate to the governments of the Member States that the text it wishes to impose on us is unacceptable.

And in the chorus of praise that will undoubtedly soon fill the ears of the French government, it seems to me necessary to focus above all on the employees who will be called upon to work ever more, without truly having the choice, just as all those to whom we will ask tomorrow to work on Sundays in France.
It is, moreover, evidently to open up this possibility that the French government has changed its position on individual opt-out within the Council.

Dear colleagues, let us listen to the employees and try to respond to their call. If we do not want the negative votes of the French, Dutch, and Irish referendums to be followed by many others, questioning a European Union that would give them the feeling of not addressing their daily concerns, I thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. That was a very fine French presidency.
There were very few dissenting voices, to say the least.
The 27 set aside their differences to reach a series of decisions that were exemplary.
On the energy-climate package, Europe is taking a first step, and in that, this first step is immense.
It now has the means to assume its environmental responsibility without sacrificing its economy.
She can now take the lead in this area to guide other continents towards sustainable development.
Furthermore, Ireland offers a scenario for escaping its isolation.
Our Irish friends will pronounce themselves once again on the Lisbon Treaty with all the cards in hand, as practically all other members will have definitively declared their position.
Current crises demonstrate that the Union needs, more than ever, the best institutional tools to be effective.
The European Council adopted a massive and coordinated economic recovery plan, based on long-term productive investment and targeted support for the industrial sectors most severely affected.
President Sarkozy raised the issue of reducing certain VAT rates, and I fully share his perspective.
We hope that the ministers of economy and finance will reach an agreement in March, an agreement that seemed impossible to the head of state and government last weekend.
The trials faced by Europeans provide an opportunity for the Union to demonstrate itself as more united, more responsive, and more concerned with protecting them.
We are grateful to the French presidency for having spurred this new dynamic.
We wish, as did Nicolas Sarkozy, not to see again anytime soon the councils of yesterday that ended at 4 a.m. to negotiate three peanuts.
Over the past six months, Europe has indeed changed its mindset, its scope, its credibility.
We must thank the French presidency for this. We are well aware that it is not entirely unconnected to this. Thank you, Mr. President.
The situation in Gaza is known to everyone.
what we are discussing here in Parliament is natural.

But we demand that the Security Council take a position. We demand that the institutions take a position, that the European Union take a position. And we, in Parliament, discuss and are unwilling to take a position.

I believe that, even so, in the face of the urgency of the situation in Gaza, it is of utmost importance that this Parliament takes a position and states exactly what it wants to do to stop the massacres that are taking place in the Middle East at this time.
I find it unacceptable that this Parliament has not mustered the courage and clarity of judgment to vote on a resolution following our debate.
That is why our group requests a revision of the Conference of Presidents’ decision and the completion of the debate to which we must gain access.
to have a position on the situation in Gaza through a resolution that will demonstrate this Parliament's clear and firm stance, by a majority, to ensure the massacres in Gaza cease.

We want a resolution. We must be aware that we have a political responsibility regarding what is happening. And this political responsibility cannot simply be a discussion. It must be a resolution that clearly states what we want and what we condemn.
Mr. President, Commissioner, more than ever, the proposed directive that Parliament is about to vote on elicits in me a very mixed sentiment.
It is true that rapporteur Mr. Cleanse has for years carried out extensive work and has negotiated with talent, notably during the Trilogue.

It is also true that the directive has seen a number of significant advancements toward the improved functioning of the internal market, the collective management of financial assets, and has been welcomed as such by the European fund investment industry.

It remains the case that debates and discussions within the Council and the Parliament were never entirely free, since the outcome was known in advance. For certain actors, it was absolutely imperative to introduce the European passport for management companies.
In principle, there is nothing to fault. The passport holds up perfectly well. It is still necessary, however, to ensure that the introduction of a passport for management companies
accompanied by the necessary guarantees, particularly regarding fund supervision, as it results in a segregation of functions across borders.
Alternatively, I observe with regret that the system in place is not only complex, but also susceptible to divergent interpretations.
They risk soon encountering practical difficulties that will harm the European industry, particularly export funds, especially exports to third countries.
I have fully acknowledged my position as being in the minority, though I do not feel uncomfortable.
Under normal circumstances, I would have been inclined to say that only practice will allow for definitive conclusions to be drawn in the matter and thus to determine
Who is correct, those who trust in the adaptive capacities of market actors and those who adhere to a more cautious approach?
It is not out of the question that success lies ahead. But on the other hand, nothing guarantees it either.
Alternatively, very recent events, notably the Madoff scandal and its implications for the financial collective asset management industry, do not inspire confidence.
To skepticism succeeds my unease.
The investment fund industry will not be spared by the financial crisis, we are witnessing this already.
It may be that fundamental reconsiderations are necessary stemming from this crisis context.

that in these contexts of profound crisis, we operate choices that dilute the responsibilities of actors, or that presuppose perfect cooperation between regulatory authorities, can genuinely appear as an incongruity.
I tell you as I think, this erection is also that of a bygone era, before the crisis.
She is marked by a certain nonchalance.
Indeed, the financial system is poised to experience a prolonged and fundamental crisis of confidence. Entire sections of its architecture must be rethought.

Let us not forget that the primary function of OPCMs is to protect the investor through risk diversification and the establishment of strict rules. By voting on this text as it stands, without truly knowing where we are going, we are acting as if nothing had happened.
This autism doesn’t portend anything good; that is why I will abstain, even though I have signed the compromise amendments negotiated with the Council.
Given the circumstances, the improvements made appear to me, indeed, to be of little weight in comparison to the questions of principle that I have just explained.

Mr. President, although the regulations concerning the reporting of animals have been in force since January 2007, it appears that Member States are not consistently complying by providing the annual reports that were requested of them.
Consequently, a global analysis remains arbitrary, given the numerous elements lacking regarding the resources allocated to perform inspections?
As a member of animal protection associations and of the intergroup for animal defense, this subject concerns me particularly.
For decades, associations have desperately fought for guidelines to finally be established in this area, where member states exhibit a certain degree of leniency.
I would even go so far as to say a certain reluctance. For ultimately, we know that the implementation of control and inspection is not insurmountable at all.
We know the slaughter locations, we know the rearing locations, we know the transit routes of livestock. So, where is the problem?

I believe that in our time, as public opinion becomes increasingly sensitized—rightly so—by the welfare of animals, whether concerning farming conditions, slaughter practices, or transportation, it is important that states respect these sentiments.

And since the floor has been given to me, I would like to add, regarding transportation, that it would be essential to examine and take into account, irrespective of travel times, the local climatic conditions.
Indeed, a multi-hour transport in the Netherlands during springtime is not comparable to the same transport duration in full summer in a country such as Greece.
Should night transportation not be mandated in these latter cases?
Thank you for considering this proposal in the future.

I am pleased that it is a Briton, our colleague Parish, who has submitted this text, as if the Roman soldiers, 2000 years ago, did well to go to Great Britain and bring amphorae of olive oil and wine.
But then two consequences must be drawn from this.

It is not very reasonable, symbolically, to place the food agency in Helsinki. And it is not reasonable that the European Commission does not backtrack on the following points. First, reinstate subsidies for almond growers. Secondly, halt the amendments.

aggressions against olive trees, particularly in Lousie and throughout Europe; halt the aggressions against bluefin tuna fishermen in the Mediterranean; and stop the aggressions against the European vineyard through uprooting.
I suggest to our Commissioner, to our President, Mr. Barroso, that he organize a grand banquet in Portugal with sheep's cheeses and Saint-Germain wine.
Thank you, Mr. President. We have indeed all advocated for the closure of Guantanamo and we are all pleased by President Obama’s decision to close this prison of shame.
Today, the question of welcoming Guantanamo detainees should not arise for us.
As Europeans, faithful to our values of defending the dignity of each individual, we must take our responsibilities, for it is our duty to welcome these former detainees.
And we were able to read—and here I address the Council—that certain Member States were not particularly enthusiastic about this welcome.
Therefore, I would genuinely like to issue a call to the Council and, in particular, to the reluctant Member States, urging them to accept these detainees on their territory.

And I will tell you, dear colleagues, that the worst thing would be for the commendable momentum generated by the closure of Guantanamo to falter because we failed to respond when Europe called upon us.

important because the European animal feed sector is one of the most significant in agriculture, both in terms of production—representing half of the European Union's agricultural output, 120 million tonnes—and in terms of turnover, approximately 50 billion euros.
The European Union has, in fact, 5 million livestock farmers and 60 million households owning pets.

In the past, the European Union has had to manage a number of health crises, which means that today we must be more vigilant regarding transparency to meet the expectations of breeders, but also of consumers.

The provisions outlined in this report have the advantage of representing minimal cost for industries and significant benefit for consumers, who are increasingly attentive to the quality of the products they purchase.

The adoption of this report will help limit risks by guaranteeing improved product quality, enhanced control, greater traceability, and comprehensive information for the breeder and, ultimately, the consumer.
Today, with the increase in international exchanges, it is now imperative to strengthen all preventative measures to ensure that the food crises we have experienced in the past do not recur.

This report manages to reconcile the right to information while strictly defining the nutritional elements that must obligatorily appear on labels and the right to intellectual property, which is so important for preserving the competitiveness of our industries.

I believe that manufacturers should indeed be obligated to immediately notify the use of any new raw material entering the composition of animal feed, in order to guarantee transparency and facilitate control by the competent authorities.
It seems entirely indispensable to include an emergency procedure that allows for the introduction of a new hazardous substance into the list of prohibited materials.

Similarly, giving the breeder the possibility of questioning the competent national authority or the European Commission in the event of doubt regarding a misleading claim helps to better secure the system, both to protect the customer while preserving the integrity of commercial transactions.

I therefore wish to offer my full support to this excellent report, as experience demonstrates that regulation of pet food labelling prioritizing quality, transparency, traceability, and control is the best guarantee of preventing further health crises in Europe.

Ladies and gentlemen, it is certainly not Europe, nor its High Representative for Foreign Affairs, Javier Solana, former Secretary General of NATO, who can play the role of mediator between Israel and the Palestinians.
At most, they are called upon to finance the reconstruction of the Gaza Strip, as they do today for Kosovo, Lebanon, or Afghanistan?
Americans and Israelis bomb, Europeans finance reconstruction.
This is how tasks are divided among allies.
Or it would be necessary for the vandals to pay.
Egypt is at the center of peace talks focusing on an extended ceasefire with Hamas.

But the challenge to be met is formidable, as the new Israeli government, under the pressure of the third man, Lieberman, leader of an extreme right that is accepted there democratically, risks seeing its task singularly complicated in this negotiation.
Indeed, Netanyahu, who is presented as the future Prime Minister, has consistently opposed a truce with Hamas.
Another difficulty is that Mahmoud Abbas’s Palestinian Authority has become, in the West Bank, a kind of international protectorate whose legitimacy has significantly diminished among the population.
Last element to consider, the expansion of Israeli settlements, which has never ceased since 1967, makes the creation of a Palestinian state in the West Bank particularly delicate.
Today, the ball is in the Israeli camp, but do the hawks on both sides accept this truce of God that both parties demand without making the effort to achieve it?
Allow me to add a thought regarding France’s reintegration into NATO’s integrated military structure, which will be debated in conjunction with the Vatanen report.
This reintegration will entail severe obligations for France.
Indeed, we are rejoining NATO while the Cold War has been over since 1990.
Sarkozy appears to have forgotten the fall of the Berlin Wall and Russia’s return to the ranks of free nations.
Should the logic of blocs be strengthened at a time when multipolarity and the rise of emerging countries, including militarily, are occurring?
Furthermore, France's accession to the integrated structure will obligate it to reinforce its contingent in Afghanistan, while it already has 3,300 personnel deployed.
With what budget will she then finance this, when her defense budget is to fall below 2% of GDP and more than 30 regiments are to be disbanded?
Paradoxically, we will increase our budgetary contribution to join NATO while simultaneously reducing our military presence in Africa.
European defense, dear to President Sarkozy, will therefore be a pillar of the Atlantic alliance.
It merely required reading the Treaty of Lisbon and its additional protocols to be convinced of this.
Whether in matters of foreign policy or common security, the European path is a dead end that will lead only to alignment with the Americans and their allies.
It is this logic of erasure that we reject in the name of national sovereignty and independence, resting in particular on our autonomous nuclear deterrent.
Thank you, Madam President. I congratulate our three rapporteurs on this quite remarkable synthesis they have produced of the current state of our common foreign and security policy.

Sir Representative, you know this better than anyone: Europe is expected today on the global stage to take the place that is assigned to it by its economic and demographic power and the richness of its democratic and humanist values.

It must be noted that, despite the consistent expression of will by more than two-thirds of our European citizens—as you have stated—certain progress has undeniably been made over the past ten years, I grant you that. Nevertheless, it must be noted that this Europe does not yet exist.
If an illustration were needed, his disappearance in the resolution of the new drama in the Middle East would serve to demonstrate it.
There has been, and still is, a need for European presence in Gaza to play an active role both in assisting the survival of the population and the reconstruction of the
and in the fight against arms smuggling, which had allowed this territory to be transformed into a launch base for rockets of all calibers.
Despite the kind words lavished on Sharm el-Sheikh and Jerusalem, nothing has yet been done in this regard.

I reiterate here a question previously raised during the Lebanese crisis. When, Mr. High Representative, can we hope for the deployment of a European fleet in the Mediterranean, as we once had in the face of piracy?
We have the means.
Will we ever have the will?
Well, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. President, dear colleagues, the Parliament’s decision to accept the urgency requested by the Council for the
The handling of this file was unanimous both at the fisheries commission last week and this morning here in plenary session.
We are indeed all aware of the necessity for the European Union to honor the commitments made in Marrakech last November by the relevant International Commission, the CICTA.
This specifically concerns giving effect to the recommendations adopted by this organization in order to curb the persistent phenomenon of overfishing of bluefin tuna in the
in the Eastern Atlantic and in the Mediterranean, and to confront the serious dangers that result from this for the future of the species and, consequently, for fishing itself.
Two of our colleagues from the Fisheries Commission, Ms. Fraga, Mr. Romeva and Rueda, were present in Marrakech and will speak on the matter as part of this debate.
For my part, I would like to reiterate the importance that our committee attaches to this dossier, which involves the key dimensions of the common fisheries policy and the management of
the resource, fleet management, compliance with international, regional, and bilateral agreements, technical measures, and above all, control—I will return to that shortly.
This characteristic dossier, therefore, appears to us as a test of the credibility of this common fisheries policy.
For this reason, it was obviously out of the question that the implementation of the new recovery plan would proceed without consultation of the European Parliament.
I am therefore pleased that the Commission has finally chosen the only path legally and politically acceptable for implementation.
recommendations of CICTA, namely, a properly formulated settlement proposal based on Article 37 of the Treaty.

The transposition into Community law of commitments made by the Commission on behalf of the European Union within regional fisheries organizations is, in fact, not a trivial matter, and we insist that it always be carried out under the democratic control of our institution.
Fundamentally, I welcome the various measures proposed, which, although restrictive for our operators, are commensurate with the challenges at hand. And I emphasize that the most important
The importance of these measures lies certainly in those that will concern control, so true is it that without control, no restoration plan can demonstrate effectiveness.
I therefore thank you, Mr. Commissioner, for this proposal. I invite you to demonstrate as much
The resolve in the concrete implementation of the plan, once it has been endorsed by the Council, that you demonstrated in reaching an agreement satisfactory at the CICTA level.
Thank you, Madam President. Madam the Commissioner, I regret that the Council and the Commission have not yet undertaken to define territorial cohesion concretely.
The French presidency is being tested there, and I wish to commend this initiative.
Our Parliament continues to insist that this objective be applicable from the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty and that its contours be clarified as soon as possible.

I wish, following the excellent report by Mr. Van Nistelrooy, that territorial cohesion should become the legal basis guaranteeing the harmonious development of all the Union’s territories and enabling the fullest possible leveraging of the specific characteristics of each European region.
It is essential to better coordinate Community policies in order to maximize the impact of interventions in the field.
Territorial cohesion is not intended to target exclusively regions experiencing permanent disadvantage.
It must nevertheless focus on the polycentric development of the European Union as a whole, taking into account the characteristics of each territory, while preserving their diversity.
This new concept seems relevant for taking into account the outermost regions, in order to ensure their sustainable and balanced growth.

In this regard, I would like to thank the rapporteur for having incorporated in his compromise amendments my requests concerning the specific challenges faced by outermost regions in terms of accessibility and competitiveness, essential elements of territorial cohesion.
Upon reading the Commission's recent communication, entitled “RUPs, an Asset for Europe,” it appears to me that it intends to apply all available resources to the ultra-periphery.
recommendations concerning the improvement of governance in cohesion matters, thereby making the rupes the first illustration, somewhat premature, of the implementation of territorial cohesion.

I hope that the Overseas General Assembly, which will soon commence in France, proceeds in the same manner and broadly incorporates the significant territorial impact of European policies focused on areas—whose added value is undeniable.
and undeniable for
One enjoys reading the conclusions of the presidency of the last Council.
It reads like the victory communiqué of all defeated armies.
They exhibit this triviality even in the reiterated claim that the crisis ending, the EU will build a stronger economy for the future, or in the reaffirmation of a Lisbon strategy in full disarray.
Thus, as they enclose themselves within their glass tower, Eurocrats, Europhiles, and Europiomalies of all kinds ultimately cease to grasp the true scale of things.
Everyone is well aware that the Eurozone was the first to enter recession, having experienced for eight years the lowest rate globally.
but it is also the one that faces the greatest difficulties regarding its industrial competitiveness and the employment situation.
Above all, it is she who, through the general disarmament of natural defenses taken from nations, is least armed to react.
In reality, the sole merit of this crisis will be to awaken peoples lulled by the conveniences of financial anticipation and by nationalist propaganda.
Only states will possess the legitimate instruments necessary for any action of significant scope, and they will need, for this purpose, to challenge the constraints of the EU and the euro.

For the French, at any rate, it is becoming increasingly clear that there will be no salvation without France, no France without French policy, no French policy without national and popular sovereignty. Thank you, Mr. President.

Thank you, Madam President. I believe that the question of distributing food to the most vulnerable is indeed quite timely, but I believe that, at its core, the Commission's proposal does not address the underlying issue.
The question of co-financing troubles me, and I believe it is rather the question of liberalism that has guided the evaluations of the CAP in recent years that should be called into question.
Riots against hunger, the abrupt fluctuations in food prices, are persistent indicators of the limits of agricultural market liberalization.
This liberalization has always come at the expense of vulnerable populations, vulnerable producers, and vulnerable territories.

I therefore argue for policy to reclaim its authority, to take control, both at the European and global levels, and for the strategic domain of agriculture and human food, both quantitatively and qualitatively, not to be subjected to the strict laws of the market.
Certainly, there is a sense of urgency, and the Sikorsky report addresses this urgency, which I welcome, but I wish that within the framework of the reflection that is opening on the
Regarding the future of the CAP, it should be recalled that the primary objective remains to structurally combat hunger and poverty as we know them in all Member States and throughout the world.

Rural territories are capable of meeting food needs through sufficient and high-quality production. However, they must be provided with the necessary financial and human resources to fulfill this significant responsibility.
Thank you, Mr. President. In this period of economic recession, it was important that the European Union continue to demonstrate its solidarity with developing countries.
Let us recall that in 2007, the European community and its member states together contributed 60% of total development aid, making the European Union the world’s leading donor.
European development funds enable the fight against poverty while promoting economic development and democracy.

I am therefore pleased that a budget of 23 billion euros has been allocated for ACP countries for the period 2008-2013 under the 10th EDF, representing practically double the amount foreseen for the 9th EDF.
The reconciliation of accounts, in its report, concludes that the accounts of the 7th, 8th, and 9th FEDs are, in general, faithful, legal, and regular.
One can only commend the record levels of contract implementation and payments for the operationalization of the European Regional Development Fund.
However, I also note that progress must be continued to strengthen the control and monitoring system, as a significant level of error affecting certain transactions still exists.
Similarly, there is a risk that is too often overstated with regard to budgetary support, and it is my opinion that these risks should be better evaluated.
On this subject, I share the view that budgetary support should be granted only if the beneficiary country has the capacity to manage funds transparently, responsibly, and effectively.

Among the priorities on which we must work in the future, I would like to mention the integration of the FAD (Fonds d’aide au développement) into the general budget, as I will finish regarding the community, because that would strengthen the efficiency and transparency of development aid.

To conclude, Mr. President, I would also like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, the representatives of the Court, but also everyone in the Commission who has done excellent work on site. And I obviously regret the absence of the Council and, in particular, the Czech presidency.
Madam President, Parliament and its rapporteur were compelled to reject a flawed compromise. They were right to do so.
Our delegation remained faithful to the position adopted extensively in plenary session and which called for the eventual elimination of all exemptions from the legal working week.
But the truth is that the Parliament alone wanted to move things forward.
The representatives of the European people had decided beyond partisan divisions to end this anachronism known as the opt-out.
We were the only ones to propose a genuine compromise text, which the Council of Ministers superbly ignored, as did the Commission.
The Council and the Commission have aligned themselves with the position of those who fiercely oppose any progress in workers' rights in Europe.
Mr. President of the Council, it is clear that you have achieved your objectives.
The Court of Justice requires you to consider all custody time as working time. You have therefore lost nothing on that account.
The opt-out you desire still exists in practice; the status quo has therefore prevailed.
More than ever, the deputies elected next June will have to strive for a top-down harmonization of social standards.
Mr. President.

Mr. President, this is certainly not on behalf of the liberated Commission; it is likely on behalf of my group. I would like to use this brief minute to express my extraordinarily positive appreciation for Ms. Paganoff’s report.
Congratulations, Madam, on your report.

I believe that, in writing this report, you have developed an extraordinarily precise specification of elements that should rightly feature prominently, Mr. Commissioner, in the Stockholm Programme, which I know the Commission is actively preparing.

Allow me to add to everything that has been said regarding the importance of judicial training, the importance of evaluation, and to emphasize two fundamental elements in matters of mutual trust that underpin what could be tomorrow’s mutual recognition.
The independence of the judiciary.
Currently, within the Union, there are a number of countries in which the independence of the judiciary from political power or from other powers has not been established.
It is a scandal, and this scandal must end.
2. Procedural safeguards.

As long as we are not certain that in a number of countries, individuals suspected or accused of having committed certain types of offenses benefit from procedural safeguards analogous to those that exist elsewhere, it is difficult to secure widespread acceptance of the principle of mutual recognition.
It is a fundamental element, and I wanted to introduce it into this discussion.
Congratulations, Madame Pagano.
Madam President, we cannot remain silent on the situation in Madagascar. And we will not be alone in condemning it.
The African Union, the Southern African Development Community, the International Organisation of La Francophonie, the Inter-Parliamentary Union, the European Union as represented by the Commission,

The USA, a large number of countries including my own and Norway, to speak of countries on the European continent, have condemned the coup d'état, because we must call a spade a spade, which took place in Madagascar.
Therefore, we cannot remain silent and we are calling for a return to constitutional legality.
We never demand a return to the initial class with, if necessary, arbitration by the Malagasy people through a consultation in the form of a presidential election or referendum.
It falls to the assemblies and political leaders of Madagascar to determine the most effective form of consultation.

Therefore, what we are requesting with this resolution, is to add our voice to that of the international community to clearly indicate to those who have seized power in a completely non-tragic manner,

democratic and in effect, in the form of a coup d'état, however cleverly disguised, to return to the constitutional legality of Madagascar, which is one of the guarantors of the future development of this large island in the Indian Ocean.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, naturally, I would like to thank Commissioner Dimas for his presence and his responses, for the continued attention he gives to all these disasters.
We worked together extensively when President Barroso asked me to prepare a report—a report he subsequently cited—on the establishment of a European civil protection force.
I presented this report on May 9, 2006.
And when I reread it and see all the catastrophes that have occurred, I find myself thinking that it remains perpetually relevant.
Madame Zanlella, of course, there is more than just Greece.
All countries are affected. And I would add that there are not only natural disasters, but also human disasters caused by human actions.
I think of maritime disasters, the RICAS and so many others, of industrial accidents of the type of Chernobyl.
There are other natural disasters than wildfires.
I am thinking of the tsunami,
We may one day fear a tsunami in the Mediterranean, as there was one at the beginning of the 20th century that utterly destroyed the city of Messina.
Frankly, Commissioner, dear colleagues, the tools we deploy are not up to the scale of these catastrophes, which will multiply under the dual impact of climate change and transportation.
And that is why I believe we need to be more ambitious.
I thank the Commission, Commissioner Dimas, all of their teams, and the Directorate-General that operates the civil protection mechanism.
I believe that we must go further.
with those member states that wish to do so. One can envision enhanced cooperation.
If we cannot be 27 to form this civil protection force, let us begin with 12 or 15.
And then you will see that it will concern everyone.
When I make a list of catastrophes, I can say that everyone is affected. The floods that struck Germany in 2002, and even the major pandemics, and also terrorism.
There you have it, Commissioner, why I would like the Commission to take the initiative to go further, to propose to the Member States that they go further.
And our Parliament, the Environment Committee, the Defence and Security Committee, will support you in these voluntary initiatives.

Mr. President, Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen, Members of Parliament, once again this summer, the Mediterranean forest has been ravaged by flames in Marseille, in Southern Corsica, but also in Italy, in Spain, and on a larger scale in Greece.
Over 400,000 hectares of forests and fields have been consumed by fire, causing substantial material damage, irreversible harm to biodiversity, and dramatic loss of human life.
deeply dismayed by this recurring record year after year and aware of the multiplier effect of climate change on wildfires,
I call for a European awareness to improve coordination of efforts and the pooling of resources for firefighting.
I wish to see the realization of a large-scale Euro-Mediterranean cooperation project to combat wildfires within the framework of the Union for the Mediterranean.
I commend existing initiatives, and in particular the European Forest Fire Information System, a pilot project,

Nevertheless, I advocate for a reform of the European Union's Solidarity Fund so that it becomes an effective tool for responding to crises and a strengthening of the European Union’s rapid response capability.
and the EuroAid mechanism, conceived by Michel Barnier as early as 2006 to intervene within the territory of the 27 member states as well as abroad.

I believe that one of the keys to the problem of wildfires lies in the exchange of knowledge and best practices in prevention. I would like to highlight the pioneering role played by forest firefighters in my own department.
And I can, of course, make this example available to Europe, which can serve as a model. Thank you.

Good morning, Madam President, good morning, Madam Commissioner. 
Right, I will be brief.
I believe there are two elements in this debate.
The conjuncture question: how to exit this crisis?
And all measures that both assist farmers and involve intervention are necessary and absolutely necessary.
they must be supported and even considered to be more important,
This is what we are proposing with a number of colleagues here in Parliament.
Secondly, there is a question posed in a structural manner regarding the management of the milk market. And it is there that there is a divergence with you, Madam Commissioner.
You propose moving toward contractualization.
I say this in advance: contractualizing between industrialists and farmers in the long term, given that industries are competitive with each other, will lead to competition on a European scale.
We require public regulation to regulate a market.
There is no other alternative.
That is where the debate will need to begin following this crisis.
And I believe that on this debate, it is necessary to respect all opinions and all options. And I fear that we went too quickly during the health assessment to settle a question like quotas.

And so far, I say this to all those who have intervened, it has allowed both the maintenance of dairy production in Europe, the assurance of a highly developed dairy industry, and at the same time, the guarantee of a consumer price that has been, until now, entirely bearable. Thank you, Madam Commissioner.
Mr. President, just a few days after the positive referendum in Ireland, I genuinely feel that we can say we are more European today than we were before.
I truly rejoiced, fully, serenely.
Unfortunately, we remain essentially dependent on the decision of the Constitutional Court, but also on the good will of the Czech president.

A clear signal of accountability must be sent to those who hold in their hands the future of this treaty, which is vital for the Union, for our institutions, and for the 500 million Europeans that we represent.
We can no longer be held hostage by a few whose sole aim is to thwart the broader European interest.
It is legitimate for some to desire not to go further in European integration, it is legitimate to express these reservations, but it is also legitimate to allow those who wish it to progress.
Generally, the processes of ratifying European treaties too often resemble sagas or Pyrrhic victories.
Are we condemned to constantly having to push for the implementation of a treaty and its institutional reforms?
We must draw lessons from this chaotic ratification process and also, obviously, from this commitment to negotiation with a view to organizing a second ratification.
referendum in Ireland, as if it were normal to re-vote a people who have expressed themselves sovereignly, and as if it were normal for an assent to a treaty to be a bargaining chip.
It is a matter of the coherence and institutional equilibrium of the European venture.
Ratifying a treaty is a minimal requirement of loyalty and cohesion from the moment one chooses that one’s country adheres to the European Union.
We wanted to send a strong signal to citizens by ratifying the treaty for the European elections of June 2009.
What do you believe the citizen thinks today of the Treaty of Lisbon and beyond our internal cohesion and our legitimacy?
Thank you, Mr. President. My contribution concerns the deterioration of working conditions in Europe.
Today, nearly half of the world’s workers earn less than 2 dollars per day.
12.3 million people are still subjected to slavery, and over 200 million children are forced to work.
In Europe, the number of working poor is increasing day by day, and the International Labour Organization counts 160,000 work-related deaths annually due to a lack of prevention.
In this context, I would like to emphasize our responsibility towards all those who are deprived of employment and social rights, who work under undignified conditions.
of these millions of workers who suffer morally and physically, sometimes driven to suicide, or victims of cancers or chronic illnesses due to their working conditions.
It is time to move beyond the religion of working more, the pursuit of profit, and short-term competition.
The right to decent work and the strengthening of the right to work must be at the forefront of the Union’s priorities over the next ten years.
Madam President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, a challenge for humanity, a challenge for future generations.

To rise to the challenge, Copenhagen must allow for a global agreement, a single agreement, as our committee chair for the environment, Jolaï Nenoui, stated earlier. An alliance of all – industrialized nations, emerging economies – is necessary.

Today, with our debate, but also with the drafting of a resolution by our Parliament, we once again call on the European Union to maintain its leading role in this necessary policy of combating climate change.
Let us recall that it is fitting that we speak with one voice to maintain our credibility.
Indeed, we must arrive in Copenhagen with an agreement to limit the increase in global average temperature to a level that does not exceed 2 degrees above pre-industrial levels.
Yes, we owe it to Copenhagen to sign an agreement in order to achieve collective reductions in greenhouse gas emissions of 30% by 2020 compared to 1997.
But that will not be enough.
It is not only necessary for developed countries to substantially reduce their emissions, but also that developing countries contribute to achieving the objectives.

Industrialized countries must therefore provide sufficient, sustainable, and predictable financial and technical support to developing countries to encourage them to commit to reducing their greenhouse gas emissions.
Copenhagen must therefore enable developing countries to transition towards low-carbon models.
Also, allow me to address two avenues that appear necessary for our future.
First, the global establishment of climate change mitigation funding based on the taxation of financial transactions.

Subsequently, it appears necessary to implement a fiscal adjustment at the borders of Europe that will result in the pre-importation of products manufactured without any consideration for environmental protection.

a contractualization and a transfer to a Southern country of the carbon tax thus collected at Europe’s borders, which would serve to finance investments in the equipment necessary to combat global warming.

Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to speak along the same lines as my remarks yesterday regarding the preparation for the Copenhagen summit and following, furthermore, yesterday's ecofin meeting, which was not a success.
I raised the issue with you of the responsibility we, as industrialized nations, have to ensure that developing countries can keep pace with our efforts to combat climate change.
In Copenhagen, we cannot pretend that we all have the same capabilities. Otherwise, it would mean that we all start from the same point to ultimately achieve nothing.

Therefore, to convince our development partners to join us, it will obviously be necessary to address the question of the assistance that should be provided to them and not wait for the outcome of the Copenhagen summit.
At the next European Council, the 27 will absolutely need to agree on how the European Union envisions aid to developing countries within the significant context of climate change.
Yesterday, therefore, as I was saying, the Minister of Finance's advisor, Mr. Coffin, was unable to find common ground on this issue.
Yet, we know that this question is absolutely central.
The European Commission had already made proposals. I absolutely wish that we take the initiative to guide our partners towards a global solidarity necessary to overcome this climate change problem.
The efforts of the Swedish presidency to reach an ambitious agreement in Copenhagen, despite the strong wind of pessimism blowing over these future negotiations.
For my part, I believe it is not realistic to concede at this stage that the Copenhagen summit was stillborn or that it will not result in a conclusive agreement ratified by all parties.
Let us not succumb too quickly to pessimism.
I advocate that, at this stage, we do not scale back our ambitions, neither in terms of objectives nor in terms of timelines.
We must continue to believe in a comprehensive, ambitious, and legally binding global political agreement, paving the way for the conclusion of a legally sound treaty as soon as possible.
It is truly too early to discuss the deadline of the COP16 in December 2010.
We must now translate our rhetoric into genuine political will.
It is necessary to clarify our commitment in terms of financial resources and assistance to developing countries, particularly regarding technology transfers.
At this stage, a total and collective commitment from the European Union is indispensable.

I also note on paper the recent but exemplary impetus provided, or to speak of it, by Brazil, South Korea, Indonesia, Norway, among others, which have quantified their ambitions to reduce their polluting emissions.

While one can understand the flexibility sought by the United States, which is only beginning to consider the climate question, we must nonetheless reach quantified, binding, and ambitious commitments in the short, medium, and long term from other major polluters such as the United States and China.
Lacking alternatives, we run headlong into climatic, political, and moral disaster.
Madam President, we all know and we have all said the importance of the Copenhagen negotiations, but if we all hope for an agreement, we cannot accept an agreement at any price.
If the conditions for an ambitious agreement are not met, I wish to state very clearly that the European Union must be capable of saying no and refusing to sign a watered-down agreement.
The European populations we represent here expect an agreement, an agreement that allows us to effectively combat the entirety of the climatic disruptions we observe daily around us.
They will not settle for mere announcements, unquantified statements of intent, or non-binding objectives upon which one can simply walk away once the media spotlight has faded.

In Copenhagen, states must commit. The European Union, the only continent to have seen its CO2 emissions decrease since 1990, the only continent to forecast precise, binding, and ambitious commitments for the future, cannot shoulder the burden of this effort alone.

That is why, if other industrialized and emerging countries do not wish to shoulder their share of the burden, we must draw all the consequences by establishing at our borders a tax protecting our industry from the competition of those who decide not to participate in a global agreement.
We, Europeans, demand a little more each day from our industrialists.
I would like the Paris Agreement as evidence, which was signed under the French presidency.

I would like to cite as evidence the national initiatives that, like the carbon tax—applauded earlier by Mr. Parniaud, and I commend him for that—are driving the establishment of an ecological taxation system.

A sector such as transportation, which ranks among the largest CO2 emitters—even if certain modes of transport like aviation emit fewer greenhouse gases—is increasingly contributing to the fight against climate change.
Alternatively, it is a sector that has been severely affected by the backlash from the crisis.

If, as I hope, maritime and air transport are integrated into the negotiations in Copenhagen, then let us ensure that what will be asked of European industries will also be asked of those in other industrialized countries.
In Copenhagen, global public opinion will have its eyes fixed on its ruling class.
Madam President, dear colleagues, the Copenhagen summit is a historic opportunity to change the course of the planet.
We must arrive at decisions even more binding than those made in Kyoto.
We too must call upon our leaders to create an international organization, such as the WTO, responsible for regulating climate change and environmental issues, to establish a foundation.
to climate change, in addition to public development assistance, to create a maritime and air carbon tax as we must also do on financial transactions.
We readily see the pressing necessity underlying global environmental regulation, as well as that of financial markets and the Internet.
We have the opportunity to open this journey through history by way of the environment.
Let us do so, in the image of our loftiest human aspirations, lest we appear as those responsible, with no grasp on the reality of things. I thank you.

Thank you, Madam President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, dear colleagues. Less than two weeks before the Copenhagen conference, concerns are growing regarding the success of climate change negotiations.
Some, indeed, are already saying it will be a failure.
Major global powers are still reluctant to demonstrate the full ambition that the climate emergency demands of us.

By adopting the resolution tomorrow on the European Union’s strategy ahead of the Copenhagen Conference, we, Members of the European Parliament, must demonstrate that our determination is first and foremost absolute, and that the conference must result in an agreement that is certainly precise, but above all legally binding.
Furthermore, the binding nature of this agreement, once found, must not be called into question or challenged.

We cannot indefinitely postpone the decision until tomorrow, or it will be too late. Hence the necessary creation of a global environmental organization, which appears today not only necessary but also urgent, as it will, under the auspices of the UN, be tasked with overseeing the implementation of the commitments made in Copenhagen.
We must be able to expect significant pressure from this world from Copenhagen onwards, greater clarity and responsibility.

Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to express my support for the joint initiative of the British socialist government and the French government aimed at returning Afghans in an irregular situation to their respective territories.
Indeed, contrary to what some have said, these individuals had seen their application for political asylum rejected. This bilateral initiative must now be extended at the European level.
Migration pressure is a challenge that we must collectively address. This is the purpose of the migration and asylum pact, voted on and adopted several months ago under the French presidency.
We must now go further by pooling our resources and organizing joint return flights funded by Frontex.

The decision of the 27 to request from the Commission a study on this subject is a first step. Commissioner, I wish the Commission to support this proposal, as the fight against illegal immigration is an expectation of public opinion and particularly of immigrant populations in regular status. Thank you.
Mr. President, I would like to revisit a recent event, the Swiss vote on minarets.
Certainly, this vote took place in a state that is not a member of the European Union, but it is evident that it concerns a matter which is not foreign to us.
I would like to revisit this event because I also see in it the pretext for discussing secularism, and we never speak enough about secularism within this chamber.
It is necessary and urgent that the principle of secularism dominate the organization of our society. And I would like to say here a few simple things.
First, it is crucial to understand that the principle contrary to secularism is not religious belief, nor still less spirituality.
The principle contrary to secularism is religious communautarism, which dictates rules and laws superior to civil laws. Communautarism that confines individuals within groups inferior to society.
Our union, by its history, is multicultural and multi-generational.
She will become increasingly so, and only secularism can allow individuals...
The Caesar Programme, which aims to modernize air traffic management in Europe, is a major project.

How will the Commission prepare the next phase of deployment of the CERES program, and in particular the financing of this essential program for both the environment and our scientific and technical influence?
Will the Commission follow the recommendations of the 2007 report, which stipulated that a suitably qualified, high-level personality should ensure the political oversight of this programme?

Indeed, it will require overcoming numerous legal, psychological, and technical obstacles, by unifying national airspace and ensuring the collaboration of air traffic controllers from different countries.
If Europe cannot unify its airspace, how can it hope to build a strong political entity?
Thank you, Mr. President, Madam Minister, dear colleagues. The importance of the issue of climate change is no longer in question.

These impacts, whether short, medium, or long term, are undeniable, even if today the results of the GESC in a certain national newspaper are making headlines and certainly reinforce the positions of the skeptics.
The Copenhagen summit appeared to the world as a unique opportunity for world leaders to acknowledge, act upon, and rectify the effects of climate change.

The European Union was at the forefront of this discussion, not only thanks to the bold legislation that we have in place regarding the limitation of the impact of our activities on the climate, but also because Europe represents a union of countries that can genuinely make a difference.
Certainly, the outcome of the Copenhagen conference can only leave a taste of dissatisfaction, but I refuse to speak of failure.
The world has agreed on the issue of limiting temperature increase to 2°C, and this, even for a country as reluctant as China.
Brazil has just enacted a law aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions by nearly 39% by 2020, in accordance with its commitments.
Many others have also demonstrated significant ambition regarding greenhouse gas emission reduction targets,
I am thinking of Japan and Norway.
Furthermore, it is also important to highlight the very positive outcome of the consensus reached regarding the urgency of a mechanism to reduce emissions resulting from deforestation.
A specific and unanimous text was reached regarding the implementation of the Direct Plus mechanism to reduce deforestation and thereby enable natural CO2 storage.
Far from a binding agreement, but clearly in line with a political accord, the outcome of Copenhagen should lead us to question the reasons for such disappointment.
I attended the Copenhagen conference, as did many of my colleagues, with the desire to participate, to help, to witness a negotiating Europe, a leading Europe.
My disappointment was considerable, as Europe clearly did not have the place it deserved in the negotiations, particularly when it came to the European Parliament.
To assert itself, Europe must demonstrate greater strength on the matter.
The meeting of our ministers on the environment in Seville did not yield results. And our leaders have been uncertain, hesitant, and we remain divided on our objectives.
I hope that Mrs. Edegarde, drawing on her proposals and commitments made before the Environment Committee, will be able to raise the ambitions of the European Union.

Thank you. I give the floor to Mr. Bouddhiste. Dear colleagues, in order to avoid caricatures—we have heard a few this morning—I would like to recall a few objective elements concerning Tunisia, a partner country of the European Union.
The social situation has evolved very favorably, with a spectacular increase in per capita income, and now the vast majority of Tunisians meet the criteria defining membership in the middle class.

Over 90% of Tunisians benefit from social security coverage, and more than a quarter of Tunisia's budget is dedicated to education, meaning that the country ranks among the first to have achieved the Millennium Development Goals regarding primary education.
Finally, as Mr. Michel reminded us earlier, women’s rights are recognized and guaranteed.
At university, there are more female students than male students. 40% of professors are women. A quarter of members of parliament, local elected officials, or journalists are women.
Many countries could envy such results.
Thank you, Mr. President. The acts of fanatical criminals who killed Christians in Egypt cannot be attributed to an entire people and its government.
It would be unjust to hold Egypt and Egyptians accountable for this abominable massacre, the perpetrators of which will be tried.
Let us not confuse the acts of a criminal with the policy of a country. Let us not conflate fanatics with an entire population. Finally, when claiming to interpose
Between the Egyptian Coptic Christians and their Muslim compatriots, we provide arguments to extremists who seek to portray Eastern Christians as agents of the West.
What is happening in Greece, in Portugal, tomorrow in Spain or Ireland is scandalous.

These very same Anglo-Saxon agencies, which complacently noted the unscrupulous issuers and traders of toxic assets and saw nothing coming, are now exhibiting the utmost severity towards the states that rushed to the aid of a financial sector that did not deserve it.

The crisis triggered by the irresponsibility of markets and banks, and this massive aid, are directly responsible for the worsening of deficits and public debt that these same markets now claim to sanction.
That concludes the moralization of capitalism proclaimed by Mr. Sarkozy, the European Union, and the G20.

All that greenhouse banks have retained from the crisis is that the taxpayer is an inexhaustible source of profit and insurance resources. For it is widely known that the scale of this panic originates from a large American bank that benefited from U.S. government assistance.

Americans and two hedge funds of the same nationality who wish to profit both from the exorbitant interest rates imposed on Greece and from the CDS market, these insurance policies on state debts that themselves are the subject of independent speculation.
It will not suffice to regulate hessians, which you are afraid to do, or the markets for derivative instruments, as Mr. Barnier proposes.
It is pointless to create a European economic government.
The 27 are, in any case, in the same predicament, and solidarity is not an option.
It is the free global circulation of capital that must be called into question, otherwise there will be no.
Thank you, Mr. President. Less than 15% of the original bluefin tuna stock remains today.
Faced with such figures, the solution appears evident.
Nevertheless, it is important not to overlook the positions affected by the decision before us today.
It is important to recall that CITES is not intended to prohibit fishing, but only the international trade of this fish, 80% of which is exported to Japan.

By conserving tuna, we are certainly protecting a species dangerously sought-after, but we are also encouraging the maintenance of a more balanced, more sustainable fishing activity—a fishery destined for our domestic market and a source of employment.
I am in favor of listing red tuna in Annex 1 of CITES. While I believe this decision will be positive, assistance from the Commission to allow a profound restructuring of the fishing sector will be.
My question therefore concerns the modalities of this support.
France is requesting an 18-month suspension, accompanied by financial measures for seafarers and shipowners affected by a trade ban.
What is the Commission’s view on the matter?
Furthermore, my concern, like that of many of my colleagues, pertains to equity.
How can we ensure that vessels flying the flags of countries such as Tunisia, Libya, or others will apply the ban on international trade with a level of rigor comparable to our own?
What will the new control and sanction measures be?

The sustainability policy for our economic activities must be concrete, sometimes even unpopular in certain sectors, but I hope that the Commission and the Council do not lose sight of the adjustments necessary for the implementation of these measures.
Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, as the rapporteur has reported, this draft directive indeed follows a vote in Parliament, as you have also recalled, Mr. Commissioner.
However, my group remains extremely critical of this proposal because it risks backfiring on those we seek to support.
In seeking to lighten the burden on businesses, we risk depriving them of the conditions of transparency and trust essential to their management and the dynamism of their operations.
First, I believe it is important to be clear about thresholds and what are referred to as micro-entities.
These are SMEs with more than 10 employees, with a turnover exceeding 1 million euros,
Whatever the member state, this represents a very large majority of companies.
