Certainly, they may be local and have limited presence in the community market, but it remains the case that the need to present accounting rules will not be abolished for them, and that these
Accounting rules, they will have to confront them each time they wish to deal with a bank, with partners, or occasionally negotiate with fiscal, economic, and social institutions.
At that point, accounting rules will be imposed upon them, and they may have to pay more than they would for standard accounting in order to meet criteria they may not necessarily understand.
I do not see any benefit in imposing accounting obligations outside of a common framework within the European Union.
This is not simply a matter of competition. It is fundamentally a question of economic integration and of Community law, and of equal treatment for all businesses within the European Union.
That being said, it is obviously a necessity to simplify accounting obligations for SMEs.
Three initiatives, moreover, are moving in that direction—whether it be the proposal we are discussing today, or the international IFR framework.
whether it be the revision of the fourth and seventh accounting directives for which the European Commission should shortly be making proposals to us.
These proposals were promised to us for 2010; it appears they are being extended, but I do not believe this extension of the deadline is a sufficient reason for...
to rush and do a half-hearted job. For these three proposals, although they share the same objective, may not have the same articulation. And it seems to me, Mr. Commissioner,

and clearer for businesses, to provide them with a single, comprehensive response that will allow them to reconcile the objective of simplifying obligations desired by all with the day-to-day reality of small businesses that need it.
The current problem is that the European Commission is dragging its feet in proposing a revision of these directives, and this is detrimental to our thinking.

I therefore call on the European Commission to accelerate the dialogue on the question of exemption, which currently divides both European institutions and economic circles, and to undertake an impact study.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, and my dear colleagues,

As my colleague Elisabeth Morin-Chartier and other colleagues have indicated, on February 27 and 28 of last year, the violent storm Cynthia struck several French regions, resulting in 53 fatalities and extensive property damage.
The storm was of exceptional intensity. It caused devastating floods along the French coastline.
Following Madeira, Europe is concerned once again.
Brittany, the region of my colleague and friend Alain Cadec, has been severely affected.
Three French departments have been declared natural disaster zones: Brittany, Poitou-Charentes, and the Loire Valley.
Faced with these disasters, the European Union must demonstrate its responsiveness and express its solidarity.
It is not only through words and a resolution, but also and above all through financial assistance that we will be able to support the victims of these disasters.

I therefore invite, and my colleague Christophe Béchus joins me in this endeavor, the European Commission to promptly unlock the Union Solidarity Fund to assist the affected regions in coping with the damage.
This catastrophe demonstrates the relevance of Michel Barnier’s proposal to create a European civil intervention force.

Europeans must act together because disasters are multiplying and affecting our European territories, particularly our most isolated and vulnerable regions, such as islands in the Indian Ocean and the Caribbean.

Madam President, I too would like to congratulate our rapporteur, Jörg Leichtfried, on his text and his spirit of cooperation in this matter. I particularly support what concerns his proposals regarding the funding of air safety, since we are talking here about air safety and not air security.

It has been many years that our Commission has been striving to have the principle accepted that stricter security measures must be borne by the Member States. I fully support our rapporteur on this point.
Indeed, security does not concern only travelers, but all citizens. And it is the responsibility of States to take measures to combat terrorism.
It is therefore not justified that air passengers alone should bear the responsibility for financing security measures in airports and on board aircraft.
And this is all the more true in modes of transport such as rail and maritime, where States finance security measures partially or wholly, as the case may be.
And I therefore believe that we must remain firm in the face of the Council and defend amendment 32 of the report adopted by our transport committee to the very end.
So, I had another point to address briefly.

While I support the advancements in non-discrimination and transparency that the text will bring, I do not believe the purpose of this directive is to establish a single, uniform European system of safety levies.
While requiring adherence to common rules, it is necessary to allow Member States to retain their existing system of collecting fees.

And so, in states such as Spain or Italy or France, tolls are voted on by Parliament. And in this case, it must be the authority for judicial review that serves as the independent supervisory authority.
It is the purpose of amendment 40 that I hope you will be numerous in supporting when we vote on it.
Thank you, Mr. President, Commissioner. The report I am presenting to Parliament attempts to explain that in the fight against global warming, agriculture has a place and a role to play.
Nature this week reminds us that, and volcanoes in particular, can have a major impact on human activities and on the climate.
But it still requires that men, and Europe in particular, take responsibility for combating what is known as global warming.
My report attempts to demonstrate that agriculture can simultaneously continue to reduce its carbon emissions, decrease its consumption of fossil fuels, and fundamentally adopt a different behavior.
Côte has actively participated in carbon sequestration efforts, contributing globally to reduced carbon emissions and increased carbon fixation and storage.
This report attempts to demonstrate that in agriculture, a shift is needed from an approach, how shall I put it, compartmentalized, which consists of, each time a problem arises, opening a directive,
on the soils, on the water, on pesticides, what else, and to attempt to address the agricultural question with the ambition of treating it globally, systemically.

And within this approach, we should be able to identify avenues to ensure that agriculture, as I was saying earlier, not only reduces its energy consumption but also actively contributes to carbon sequestration.

It is particularly the role related to photosynthesis, to biomass, and then especially, what is dear to me, linked also to the soil, to that capacity that European soils have to sequester organic carbon.

And I believe this avenue that I am opening in this report, and which I hope will be followed during the vote that will take place in Périer in Brussels, should allow European agriculture to enter a phase of sustainability, to ensure a

a transition to an ecologically sustainable agriculture, which would put it ahead of a number of other continents or agricultural systems, ensuring that it is capable of being economically viable, ecologically efficient, and, I believe, socially effective from that point forward.

Therefore, this report addresses a specific issue: the fight against climate change and agriculture, but it aims, I hope, to open up other avenues for fostering, in particular, the debate that will take place on the future of agricultural policy after 2013.
And I address the Commission, I will address, and I have done so often, to the agricultural committees, I will also address the various ministers when I have the opportunity.
I believe we need to take a turn.
This 2013 CAP needs to be ambitious.
She must rely on objectives that enable citizens to understand why we need a common agricultural policy.
We need a common agricultural policy because Europe's agriculture must ensure both food security and commit to the path of sustainability.
That is, at any rate, what I propose in this report, and that is what I hope the Parliament, in a large majority, will follow.

Thank you, Mr. President. I would first like to emphasize that the precautionary principle implemented by most European governments in closing their airspace in a targeted and temporary manner has been a wise and prudent decision.

The safety of our citizens must take precedence over any other consideration. And under these circumstances, the attitude of certain airlines demanding the complete and immediate reopening of airspace on the basis of one or two test flights appears, to say the least, indecent.

So I believe it was Mr. Hénin earlier who spoke of the complementarity of modes of transport, particularly with the train. And I will seize the opportunity to say how much I regret that the air paralysis...
had been exacerbated in certain countries, such as France, by the disorganization of rail transport due to strikes in these irresponsible and incomprehensible circumstances.
Returning to our subject, I wish to commend the Commission's decision to authorize the provision of public aid to airlines affected by the ongoing disruptions.
It is a sensible decision in a context already marked by crisis, but this assistance must be of an exceptional nature.

And in this regard, I wish to see, among the criteria retained for the ROC 3, the exemplary nature demonstrated by companies in the compensation allocated to their clients who were victims of flight cancellations.
Indeed, it is unacceptable that certain companies exploit the force majeure clause to evade their obligation to compensate passengers as stipulated in Regulation 261-2004.
Travelers are victims of the current situation, and if no alternative solution is offered to them, they should not additionally bear the financial cost.
Furthermore, travel agencies are exempt from the obligation to refund to travelers unused flights.
And this too is not normal.

Companies like travel agencies have insurance policies that cover them in exceptional circumstances, such as the one we have been experiencing for the past few days, and it is therefore essential to ensure that travelers are properly compensated for canceled flights.
Thank you, Mr. President. Turmoil, chaos, paralysis, cacophony, catastrophe, disaster—the words are not lacking in the press to evoke the closure of European airspace and its consequences.
I will not dwell on what has already been said, particularly regarding the magnitude of the colossal, abyssal—one might be tempted to say—financial impact of this crisis, both direct and indirect.

While I welcome the prospect of considering exceptional public aid for the aviation sector, a measure already strongly endorsed since September 11, 2001, I remain perplexed by the European approach to crisis management.

Given that 750,000 European passengers have been affected, a significant number of whom remain stranded across the globe. Given that the economic losses are escalating with each passing moment. How can one explain that it took…
Not one, two, three, or four, but five days for the European Transport Ministers to meet via teleconference to coordinate their actions and decide on the creation of differentiated traffic zones.
Two, no one contests the absolute necessity of applying the precautionary principle as a priority. But today, as traffic is progressively being reauthorized in zones

Assured, with stable weather conditions and while the volcano remains active, one is justified in asking what additional safety guarantees for passengers we could not have provided earlier, more swiftly.

Three. An evolving action model has been developed. Evolution according to the weather and volcanic activity can change by the hour. Who will continue to perform the updated assessment of corridor safety?
Should these test flights be conducted by civil aviation and airlines?

Finally, if this situation persists, worsens, or recurs—which is probable—the management model implemented will need to provide for greater coordination among Member States and special operational procedures based on real data, improved

coordination of other modes of transport in exceptional circumstances, but let us also consider the necessary coordination of assistance for the repatriation of the tens of thousands of stranded passengers, who also have the right to information and support.
Alternatively, until now, only isolated and national initiatives have been undertaken.

Thank you, Madam President. I wanted, in turn, after other speakers, to express my gratitude to our colleague Mendès Divigo, who has accomplished remarkable work under sometimes impassioned and always fascinating conditions.
The debates within the Committee on Conventional Affairs were protracted. They lived up to the significance of the matter and to the intensity and interest that are, of course, demonstrated by the
European parliamentarians in the major subject that concerns them above all and in a perfectly legitimate manner: the composition of our assembly and the procedures for designating its members.
Once again, the rapporteur has managed to gather and synthesize, I would say, into an extremely balanced text, opinions and viewpoints that were sometimes divergent.
I wanted to thank him for it.

I believe that the recommendations of these two reports, both regarding the convening of the General Council and regarding the transitional measures for the composition of our Assembly, are grounded in realism, pragmatism, and effectiveness.
It is, I believe, what citizens generally expect from Europe, on other subjects as well.
Mr. President, Mr. Dalí, Mr. Commissioner, with considerable conviction, this draft report, as just presented by Mr. Péterlé, reprises the lines
Director of Communication for the European Commission and is also inspired by the European Parliament resolution of 10 April 2008 on combating cancer in our European Union.

Allow me to underscore the objectives of the European partnership envisioned by the European Commission to combat cancer more effectively, be it the importance of prevention and early detection, the development of a new model for cancer prevention, and above all, the reduction of inequalities within the Member States.
I share the concerns and apprehensions expressed within the European Commission’s communication and the draft report.
I would like to acknowledge the work done by Mr. Péterlé, rapporteur, in the preparation of this report, and the compromise proposals put forward to address the various amendments.

As rapporteur fictif for the Socialists and Democrats group, I have wished, among other things, to emphasize the following points. Firstly, the increase in annual cancer deaths caused by exposure to carcinogens in the workplace, but also the importance of improved access to information.
Please provide the French text you would like me to translate. I am ready when you are.

containing carcinogenic chemical substances and to strengthen the control of chemical substances within the European Union. And finally, the development of guidelines for a common definition of disability that could include individuals suffering from chronic illnesses or cancer.
These are the questions we wished to pose while offering our support to this report project.
Yes, thank you, Madam President. The oil rig leak in the Bay of Mexico is a genuine ecological and economic disaster.
It appears that irregularities have been noted in the United States Department of Homeland Security's issuance of forest permits.
This would constitute a pardonable lightness, the consequences of which are incalculable and do not concern only the United States of America.
When we know that hundreds of offshore drilling permits are granted by states worldwide, if these permits are issued with the same ease, it would pose a very serious problem for the entire world.
elected officials from European outermost regions and territories with overseas populations (OTs) composed entirely of islands, almost entirely of islands, nearly 130.
In total, distributed across the three continents, I must express here my very great concern for our islands with regard to offshore petroleum exploitation projects.
This is precisely why it is imperative that the European Union, leading by example, rigorously reviews the safety and prevention measures on its own offshore oil platforms.
Furthermore, accidental or operational oil spills at sea, not necessarily attributable to Europe, are estimated at several tens of thousands of tonnes annually.

Would it not be appropriate for the European Union to take initiatives to ensure that offshore platforms now fall under the jurisdiction of an undisputed international scientific authority, established in the form of an international agency?
Following Copenhagen and in preparation for Cancún, the European Union would be honored to initiate genuine global governance for the research, protection, and exploitation of marine resources.
Building on the Barcelona Process, the Union for the Mediterranean represents an opportunity for the development of our relations with the countries of the eastern and southern Mediterranean basin.
As Vincent Péion’s excellent report rightly points out, we cannot disregard either the potential of this region nor the perils it embodies.

Yet, possessing the lucidity to acknowledge it, since the bombardment of Gaza and with the continuation of the colonization of Palestinian territories, the Union for the Mediterranean finds itself in a deadlock.
The political aspect is stalled.
We are not even certain that the summit scheduled for next June in Barcelona will actually take place.
I would not be surprised if we learn in the coming hours or days that he is on a day’s leave of absence.
We must not, however, abandon hope. But the European Union must take on greater responsibility in seeking a political solution.
We cannot leave to the United States the monopoly on the political management of the crisis in this region, which is ours, by merely contributing to its development.
The development and stability of the Mediterranean region underpin our security and growth, and for that reason, the Union for the Mediterranean remains the best instrument at our disposal.
Mr. President, Commissioner, this concerns a matter of extreme importance regarding consumer protection.

A recent survey indicates that the situation regarding food security has deteriorated in the eyes of Europeans over the past ten years. And one in three consumers remains wary regarding the quality of products.
Therefore, updating, simplifying, and clarifying food labelling within the European Union is an obligation for improved consumer protection.
Allow me to address two points.
Regarding the color code, we are in favor of this color code provided that it is accompanied by a reference to the nutritional values expressed as a percentage.
And then, I am opposed to mandatory nutritional labeling for wines and spirits.
We desire the development of regulations specific to wines and spirits within the next three years, instead of the five years proposed by the European Commission.
That is what I wished to indicate, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner.
Madam President, High Representative, this attack on civilian ships by Israeli commandos obviously demands an impartial and credible investigation.
But what credence could we give to a commission that would be both judge and party?
This attack occurred in international waters; it therefore concerns the international community, and is of particular interest to Europe bordering the Mediterranean.
Europe, which should make itself heard more and engage more forcefully in the search for a political solution based on two states, each having Jerusalem as its capital.

Europe makes substantial financial efforts to contribute to the development of Palestinian territories, but unfortunately, it is too absent from the political process that should lead to the creation of this Palestinian state.
The financial and budgetary good will we demonstrate is not sufficient.
We must also express political will and take steps to ensure our voices are heard.
The abrupt movement of the Mavi Marmara by the Israeli military elicits emotion and condemnation.
Emotion at the sight of the nine victims of the civilian assault, condemnation because this detention in international zones constitutes a violation of international law.
In doing so, the Israeli government penalizes its people, for ultimately we see, with the strengthening of extremists, the ultimate objective of security in the region drifting further away.
Yes, more than ever, the government of Israel must renounce the policy of force.
I wish, however, to note that the extensive media coverage surrounding the Mavi Marmara flotilla, orchestrated from Turkey, casts doubt on the exclusively humanitarian purpose of this operation.
An investigation appears indispensable to shed light on the assault, but also on the preparations that preceded this expedition.
I wish that the government of Israel would accept that this investigation includes substantial international participation, in order to finally find its way back to justice in this region. Thank you.
Madam President, Madam High Representative, I welcome the new momentum generated by the launch of the Partnership for Modernisation and its pragmatism.
This new partnership, even if it served only that purpose, would at least have the merit of highlighting how essential Russia is as a geopolitical partner for the European Union.
I also welcome the positive remarks regarding cooperation with Russia in crisis management.
Some observations, however.

While the requirements of the Union are consistently emphasized, the interests or positions of its partner appear systematically undervalued or dismissed, whether in the realm of energy or in how it can assess the Eastern Partnership and the Atlanticist aspirations of its closest neighbors.

I also note that the firmness displayed by most Member States and the Union in their pronouncements, the virulence of the condemnations of human rights violations, appears to be reserved solely for Russia.

The remarks are more assertive, the diplomacy more muted, as if dealing with China, for example, regarding these systematic violations of the rule of law, not least concerning the Laogai, this global factory in disregard of minimal European social requirements, while our French or European workers are unemployed.

Allow me to recall the adage “Ad angusta per augusta”—“Towards the summits, through narrow paths”—for it is thus that I view Russia’s current endeavors, freed from the criminal poison of Marxism that for so many decades has drained and confined this country.
The current Russian Federation has demonstrated its ability to raise the head of an entire nation despite the significant difficulties and challenges that remain to be addressed.

So, a little modesty, gentlemen Europeanists, especially when the European super-state itself fails to achieve any of its grand objectives despite increasingly costly resources and the progressive dominance of states in Western and Central and Eastern Europe.
I cannot also refrain from noting that this assembly displayed greater leniency toward the Soviet Union than toward Russia.

It is, moreover, often the very same individuals who yesterday championed the unilateral disarmament of the West and participation in Mr. Gorbachev's common house, who today experience the most virtuous indignation and the greatest sense of propriety regarding the Union-Russia partnership.

On this subject, I must inform you, if you are not already, of new historical facts that will emerge from the progressive translation of Soviet secret archives that a courageous Mr. Pavel Stroilov has managed to obtain. Archives that have already yielded and will continue to yield significant

An unpleasant surprise to the dogma of a singular perspective regarding the reality of the end of the Cold War, which was, in truth, Mr. Gorbachev's, and the dereliction of today's European powers who then eagerly sought to make certain Soviet projects feasible.
at the risk of repeating myself, Russia is an essential and strategic partner for European states, and our relations must be strengthened to the benefit of all parties.

This country is far closer to us in terms of culture, civilization, history, geography, mutual interest, or shared risk than are certain states you are nevertheless preparing to admit to the European Union.
Mr. President of the Council, it is often said that necessity makes law.
Faced with the crisis—I should say, a necessity that has become unavoidable—that of innovating, of being creative.

In this regard, I welcome the step taken by the Council, a step that I hope will ultimately be a giant leap, leading us toward genuine economic governance, for let us not be mistaken, the mere coordination of economic policies will remain insufficient.
Can we achieve a genuine budgetary federation, not forced by circumstances, but because we ourselves would have decided upon it?
Let us return to the Council’s decisions that nonetheless please me.
Strengthening the preventative pillar of the Stability and Growth Pact is an excellent thing, but there is no genuine fiscal discipline without sanctions for those who fail to comply.
They have been strengthened, but not yet specified. This is regrettable.

Otherwise, I will express my satisfaction, among other things, with respect to the decisions made, such as the celebrated competitiveness evaluation dashboard—for that is precisely what it concerns—reconnecting with competitiveness and sustainable growth for all.
There continues to be debate regarding the proposal to establish a bank tax, the acceptance of a tax on financial transactions, and the acceleration of the reform of financial regulations.
Mr. President of the Council, these decisions and orientations appeared only a few months, or even a few weeks, ago to be unrealistic, illusory, or even genuinely hypothetical.
You are right; it's true, it's a profound cultural shift on the scale of European incremental policy.
That being said, it is now absolutely necessary that, in October, the states implement these guidelines very concretely.

It will now depend on the Council whether the step taken is a historic giant leap or merely a pious wish, something we will all bitterly come to regret and, in particular, a majority—the citizens—will have to endure on a daily basis. Thank you.

Mr. President, we have, in fact, already discussed this at the Conference of Presidents. Many groups are divided on this Gallo report, and it is evident that Parliament, all groups, still need to discuss because there are contradictory points that the groups have not been able to resolve.
Therefore, this is why we requested postponing the debate and the vote on the Gallo report, that is, to September, September 2nd, when we will need to consider the Conference of Presidents.
Therefore, it is a very straightforward matter.
Given that the fruit is not yet ripe, let us allow it the summer to ripen and discuss the matter in September.

Thank you, Madame the President. I confess to struggling to follow my colleagues who so enjoy flexing their muscles and claiming a monopoly on our legitimacy vis-à-vis the other institutions of the Union.
Unfortunately, their posture is often ludicrous.
But when the members of this house, through hard work and conviction, assert a reasoned position,
We are defending what appears to be a common European interest against rigid states; the situation is changing completely.
In this debate on European oversight, the Parliament played that role.
Regarding the European Systemic Risk Board, of which I am the fictitious rapporteur for my group, I, along with Ms. Goulard as rapporteur, have advocated for an ambitious approach.
I have advocated for mechanisms ensuring a degree of efficiency and I have emphasized the primacy of the European Central Bank.
Why?
Because the European Central Bank is the only community institution within this framework, and because it has demonstrated its seriousness.
Out of Christian charity, I will withhold the names of all the institutions and all those prominent figures who abruptly disappeared during the storm.
We can declare ourselves happy to have had at least one captain on board during the height of the crisis.
I will therefore be reassured to see tomorrow the macro-prudential oversight underpinned by a strong community institution, whereas micro-prudential oversight will necessarily remain fragmented.
We have become so distracted, the European Systemic Risk Board must get to work as quickly as possible.

The future will reveal whether adjustments will be necessary, but it is essential to proceed from a sound foundation, as systemic risks affect the entire European and global banking sector. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. The final agreement reached on the overhaul of the Industrial Emissions Directive is more than acceptable, and I commend the work of compromise that has been achieved.

This final package summarizes the key points of the position I defended with several of my colleagues within the Environment Committee, aiming to make this text an ambitious yet realistic piece of legislation.
Firstly, maintaining a degree of flexibility for businesses and the relevant authorities regarding the granting of exemptions.
Next, I wish to acknowledge the new version of the ESN, which has been so controversial and which, now limited to certain sectors, appears much more feasible.

It is also important to emphasize that the agreement reached allows for better articulation with the ETS Directive and definitively removes from the text of the new directive the irrelevant idea of creating a market for SO2 and NOX quotas.
However, some caveats should not be overlooked, and particularly those concerning land.
As the SOL directive remains pending, this significant issue will regrettably be addressed only by Member States possessing their own legislation.
Tomorrow, Parliament must adopt the elements of the agreement reached following the trilogue negotiations.

A tremendous amount of work has been undertaken on all sides to prevent this text from being referred to conciliation, a text which, I must recall, is of crucial importance both to industry and to European environmental policy.
Madam President, each day brings its share of information that shows the extent of the ecological catastrophe caused in the Gulf of Mexico by the rupture of the offshore platform.
But let us not forget that other disasters of this kind occur elsewhere.
I am thinking in particular of what is happening today, as well as what has been happening there for a long time now in Nigeria.

That is why, in addition to the moratorium on new drilling, I believe there is a need to promote stricter rules regarding platform management, not only European regulations, but also international ones.
As for the European Union, I believe it is necessary for it to proactively equip itself with measures to combat this disaster, and I believe it is evident.
also that all of this argues, as Madame Damanaki has said, for a firm and resolute choice in favor of clean and renewable energies.
and the European Union should lead by example in this regard.

Mr. President, Commissioner, reopening negotiations with Mercosur as the European Union prepares to redefine its agricultural policy reveals a dangerous lack of coherence on the part of the Commission.
Europe already imports 500,000 tonnes of beef.
A new opening of our market will occur at the expense of breeders from disadvantaged European zones, without guarantee of respect for sanitary and social standards.
We cannot accept it.
Europe purchases 38 million tonnes of soybeans and animal feed.
These imports from Brazil and Argentina monopolize over 19 million hectares.
They are concentrated in the hands of three companies: Cargill, ADM, and Bunge.
Between 2001 and 2004, soybeans destroyed over 1.2 million hectares of tropical and equatorial forests.
It was one of the primary causes of the increase in greenhouse gas emissions and the loss of biodiversity.
The European Parliament has decided to produce a report on regaining autonomy in plant-based proteins for livestock feed.
Environmentally responsible agriculture and the fight against climate change dictate this choice.
These efforts will be rendered null and void by this bilateral agreement project.
Once again, the European Commission is selling out its agriculture and farmers to obtain random concessions for service companies.
These concessions will serve no purpose for the peasant families of Mercosur, but the interests of agro-industrial groups.
To be convinced, it is sufficient to read the Tyson group's report. An American company, a major player in the international meat market,
who announces having invested in Brazil to, I quote, and this is in their report, “use this country as a platform for exporting to Europe.”
Other companies, such as Doux, had already anticipated this move by acquiring the Brazilian group Frango Soul in 1998.
Many poultry farmers, particularly in Brittany, had been affected by this operation.
Europe, without wishing to pursue its policy of relocation by amplifying its attacks.
against the peasants. We must stop
Yes, Mr. President, many colleagues are concerned about the potential consequences for European agriculture resulting from the reopening of negotiations for an association agreement with Mercosur.
My group and I share these concerns.

It is indeed a concern, and as a Member of Parliament representing an outermost region, I have experience with banana accords. It is therefore to be feared that an agreement with Mercosur will impose a difficult cost on many European agricultural sectors.
This is precisely why an impact study is absolutely necessary.
It is also to be feared that this agreement may further tilt Mercosur's agriculture a little too much towards productivist agriculture at the expense of smallholdings that exist in these countries.

A balance must therefore be found so that this agreement does not transform the Latin American and European continents into superpowers essentially rooted in the dogma of mercantilism. Thank you, Mr. President. Thank you, Mr. Rowe.
Thank you, Mr. President. I simply want to say that we may not have structured our agenda particularly well today.
If we allow free trade agreements onto European territory, products that do not respect either our social standards or our environmental standards will render the reform of the CAP meaningless.
Very clearly, we cannot remain in a state of hypocrisy where, on the one hand, we impose environmental, health traceability, and safety constraints,
to our farmers on the grounds that it is necessary to protect consumers and, on the other hand, to allow products that can enter our continent freely without respecting these standards.
The question underpinning the negotiations with Mercosur is precisely this one.

And the way in which events were initiated, regardless of what we are told about the fact that Parliament was very well informed and that everything transpired with the greatest transparency and clarity, does not lead us to form a positive assessment of a negotiation that unfolds while, in parallel, negotiations continue at the WTO.
In the name of consistency, consumer protection, and the protection of our farmers, I do not believe that we should continue down this path.

Thank you, Madam President. I would also like to acknowledge the work done by the rapporteur, José Bové, to acknowledge the Commissioner, and then the contribution of Mr. Dess, who spoke before me, regarding the objectives of this report.

I believe it is very important that we keep in mind that in the debate we are having, we have to address a problem related to price volatility in agriculture and particularly to the fact that when prices increase,
They are very quickly reflected at the distribution level. And when prices decrease at the production level, there is no reflection among consumers.
Therefore, there is indeed a problem with the organization of the sector, and there is indeed a problem with the distribution of what is termed added value within the sector.

And I believe that José Bové’s report offers, on several points, perspectives that must be highlighted, and there I am truly addressing the Commission, to attempt to break free from this fundamentally negative spiral.
The first, of course, is the organization of the sector and the balance of power within it.
What proposals do we put forward to ensure that producers, gathered together, organized, and more influential within the sector, are able to negotiate?
That is the question you raised, Mr. Interprofessional Commissioner, but it is also a question posed on the basis of the contract that will be put in place.
And I argue, and it is stated in the report, that this contractual basis is a European framework.
One cannot allow each country to resolve this issue.
There must be a European framework.
It must be flexible, but it must exist.
It is a proposal, an inextricable avenue for me.
Secondly, of course, the question of price transparency.
Regarding that, I am in favor of establishing this observatory, which is absolutely necessary to inform consumers about price fluctuations.
Therefore, I support the proposals that are being made and I hope, as Mr. Desse said, that there will be a majority to follow suit.
Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I wished today to commend this debate, which once again underscores the need for the Union to recognize and value its regional diversity.
At this time of negotiation for the new framework programmes 2014-2020, it seems important to highlight the adjustments that should benefit specific regions.
Issues of territorial continuity and cohesion must be at the center of our concerns.
But the development of mountainous, insular, or sparsely populated territories requires more than a set of exceptional measures.
We require a horizontal approach.
We must establish instruments capable of enabling all areas of community action to coexist synergistically, thereby reinforcing their added value.

Furthermore, as representative of the outermost regions and overseas countries and territories, I eagerly await the Union’s new strategy for the OCTs, which the Commission services have promised us for early 2011.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, first I concur with my colleague's position regarding the Council’s absence from this parliamentary meeting.
I find it somewhat nonchalant on the part of the Council, and I wish to state that as well.
As the next summit on October 6th approaches, China and the European Union must absolutely and resolutely seek to advance together on the issue of climate change.
Last year, at the same time, we were already engaged in this very chamber urging Europe to do everything possible to achieve an ambitious and binding agreement in Copenhagen.
We observed that the result did not meet our expectations and ambitions.
So, the concerns a year later are the same, if anything even more pronounced.

To enable us today to constrain or convince our partners, we must demonstrate that our resolve is absolutely unwavering, showing, for instance, that we provide the means to honor our commitments to Southern countries.
For this, the establishment of innovative funding mechanisms, and I heard yesterday President Sarkozy’s speech at the UN, becomes a necessary certainty.
Therefore, for example, the implementation of a carbon tax at our borders is not to be ruled out.

It would act as an incentive mechanism for countries that are not going far enough in their climate commitments, and much more than a threat ultimately. And a means of protecting our jobs and businesses, particularly to better navigate the post-crisis period.

Thank you, Madam President. For me, the need to revalue family leave is self-evident. Raising the minimum threshold for maternity leave is an advancement, a benefit, and one should not be entirely populist when comparing the economic impact to the qualitative benefit, which is difficult to quantify.

But the problem is essentially of two kinds. 1. The economic context, it is true, but not sufficient to leave millions of families stranded for decades. 2. The legal shortcomings of the report, as the text contains several types of family leave whose legal foundations are not reconcilable.
Let us consider the adoption leave, which appears in the text on the same footing as maternity and paternity leave.
As an adoptive mother, and for all those whom I represent, I personally value the desire to grant equivalent rights to biological mothers.
I am, in fact, the small additional package mentioned by Mrs. Morin, added to the Estrella report.

If the objective is indeed to strengthen the health and rights of women, of all women in the workforce, adoptive mothers, becoming mothers in the same way as others, are entitled to the same rights and the same workplace protections.
These are mothers like any others, whom she adopts, for instance, a child of 12 months or so—no discrimination, please, as she is depicted in the text.
Regarding adoption, I regret that the text was so little explored.
It was not even informed by the Ramboll impact study.
All of this is not well developed, which is clearly a weakness.

Nevertheless, despite these reservations, I will support the report by Ms. Estrella, because beyond economic considerations, there are men and women who must not only better assume their parental responsibilities in a society of

increasingly disillusioned with the education of these young people, but also because it is our duty to ensure that no one has to choose between sacrificing their children for their work or sacrificing their work for their children.
Finally, we do not sit on the Council, but in Parliament. If we, directly elected representatives, are not ambitious, tell me who will be.
Thank you, Madam President, Commissioner, and President of the Council. I would like to speak and revisit the debate as it has unfolded thus far.
We discussed the 2011 budget with the constraints we know, namely those of a deep crisis that Europe is experiencing, with public deficits at the national level, which can lead to two hypotheses.
These national public deficits constrain the European deficit, where these national deficits must give a new direction and a renewed impetus at the European level.
That is the question.
And I ask you, Mr. Commissioner, above all, to try to think, when discussing a budget revision, when we begin to talk about budgetary perspectives for post-2013, to not…
remain entirely immersed in the context of the crisis. Unless you tell me, and tell all the citizens of Europe, that, indeed, Europe will remain in crisis for a long time.
Our entire problem, indeed, is to manage the crisis and to reduce our deficits and debt. But it is also to prepare for the exit from the crisis.
And it is there that the budgetary question arises.

We will not be able to emerge from the crisis, as Joseph Dehôde stated immediately, unless the European budget, because it is European, is capable of providing us with the means to regain what we lack today: growth, job creation, innovation, and research.

That is the crux of the matter. And it is on those terms that the budget should be discussed, rather than, as too often happens, constantly integrating the question of the crisis, the question of deficits. And in that regard, the Council is excellent.

I noted that in Deauville, Angela Merkel and Nicolas Sarkozy even announced in advance a reform of the treaties, without even having discussed anything at all with Mr. Van Rompuy, to sanction all the states that would not respect budgetary discipline tomorrow.

Here is where we stand today at the Council, while Parliament is asking for only one thing, and particularly of the Commission, it is to try to move the European project forward. And this is happening through the budget.
So you have noted a number of points on which we are entirely in agreement.
There is a need for greater flexibility.
Clearly, we must find a way together to develop a much more flexible budget. Because these are necessities; the responsiveness of Europe is at stake.
This also, of course, involves setting priorities and ensuring the budgetary efficiency of the European Union.
We will all agree on this. All in agreement. It is a necessity.
But where we need to be clear with each other is that we need a timeline. We need to set goals together, Commissioner. It cannot remain just words, just commitments, just

Texts that are, incidentally, very interesting and which I virtually agree with 100%. But now, we need to get down to specifics. And particularly regarding a key issue around which we are revolving: own resources.

How do we secure our own resources for tomorrow for Europe? Not for Europe, but for all European citizens. And to rediscover, together, a path towards growth and an even stronger path for Europe tomorrow.
It falls to you, Commissioner.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to focus my remarks on the preparation for the upcoming G20 summits.

Everything has been said by previous speakers regarding European economic governance, on the necessity of strengthening European economic governance, of reinforcing the Stability and Growth Pact, and of better involving the European Parliament and, of course, also national parliaments in the process.
I would like to briefly cite two challenges facing our nations and facing the members of the G20 that, in my opinion, must be addressed within the framework of the upcoming G20 meetings.
the challenge of currency wars and that of commodity price volatility.
I believe that on these two subjects, which are genuine threats to global growth and cause significant imbalances on our planet, the European Union must…

to organize themselves, to establish common positions, to equip themselves with the means of speaking with one voice at upcoming G20 summits, Seoul, but also those that will follow, and more broadly on the global stage. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. Dear colleagues, I would first like to congratulate our colleague Diogo Feio on the quality of the report and on the ambitious proposal it contains.
Therefore, it also demonstrates that the European Parliament is taking its full place in a debate that is decisive for the future of Europe, and we can only welcome this.
Moreover, the Greek crisis revealed the dysfunctions undermining the economic governance of the European Union.
Therefore, I take note of Mr. Feillot’s proposal to establish a permanent mechanism for financial stability.
We must also address the problem at its root.
For this, I believe the solution also lies in strengthening the stability and growth pact, and particularly the sanctions.
It is indispensable if we want a lasting improvement in the budgetary situation of the States, which is not always popular.
It is restrictive, but we have no choice.

I believe the report clearly demonstrates the stakes involved in the marine environment concerning fishing, aquaculture, transport, tourism, energy, mineral and biological wealth, and research combined with climate change.
It is a considerable potential for development that should be secured, protected, and sustainably enhanced, as the future of humanity depends on it.
The report also rightly notes that the European Union is the world’s leading maritime power and that its outermost regions afford it the largest exclusive economic zone globally.
In light of such an observation. It therefore falls to the European Union to implement an ambitious policy, a comprehensive maritime policy.
If it is not the world’s foremost maritime power doing so, who else will?
However, it must be noted that the resolution does not go very far in this direction.
It is not with 50 million euros that one can claim to occupy a position of leadership in global politics.
Finally, while overseas regions possess a recognized strategic position, being present in all oceans, a shift would have been possible.
It was judicious to have them play a major role in a grand ocean strategy, which, unfortunately, the report did not adopt, and I regret that. Thank you, Mr. President.
Madam, Sir Commissioner, I would like to revisit the anti-counterfeiting agreement currently being negotiated, particularly with the United States.
This agreement also raises questions in the United States, particularly among officials at the United States Patent and Trademark Office.
Furthermore, 75 American law professors have just sent a letter to President Obama.
He deems that ACTA, a simple executive agreement, would be contrary to the U.S. Constitution.
As the European Parliament prepares, as you know, to adopt a resolution on the ACTA agreement, which continues to raise significant concerns and is far from achieving unanimous support.
Among our fellow citizens, I believe it would be useful to have from our American counterparts a very clear response. On two points, can ACTA be ratified by the United States?
Is it, in their view, a binding or voluntary agreement?

Indeed, an anti-counterfeiting agreement already lacking the participation of China, India, and Brazil, and which would not be implemented by the United States, would substantially lose its credibility.
Thank you.

Thank you, Mr. President. Throughout this difficult birthing process of the directive on alternative investment funds, I have consistently advocated for the principle of equal treatment between fund managers, whether or not they are based in the European Union.
This principle sounds like an obvious truth, but this obviousness has encountered countless difficulties.
The result presented to us today is of a satisfactory nature.
I thank the negotiators and especially our rapporteur, Mr. Gauzès, who, after this particularly difficult process for him, deserves a substantial period of leave.
I would particularly like to emphasize that the issue of the treatment of third countries must be observed in two ways, whether one is inside or outside the European Union.
thanks notably to the European Parliament, all funds sold within the European Union will effectively be subject to comparable regulation.
One can therefore speak of a “level playing field” to a greater or lesser extent.

However, during the transitional period, non-European Union entities will benefit from the national placement regime, while funds and managers from the European Union will be subject to the directive, which is generally stricter.

The situation differs for markets located outside the European Union. There, European funds and their managers will remain subject to the directive, which is not the case for funds from third countries.
It will therefore be much more difficult to sell European products in the rest of the world, as they will be less flexible and more culturally specific.
We must be aware of this disadvantage, even if it was, in part, unavoidable.

Regarding custodians, let us also know that we will make this function more stringent, particularly due to the new responsibilities that will be incumbent upon them. Their enhanced role should result in substantial changes to the profession.

Mr. President, I am not saying this to demonstrate my opposition, but to indicate that this new regulation is far from trivial. Its implementation, which is necessary, will also entail difficulties of which we must be aware.

Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, particularly at the start of the 21st century, patients need appropriate information to be fully involved in their care pathway, to know where to seek care, to decide on the best treatment in agreement with healthcare professionals, and to strictly adhere to the prescribed treatment.
Today, patients demand independent, comparative information tailored to individual needs.
Unfortunately, the proposed revisions to the directive transmitted by the European Commission did not adequately address the needs expressed by European citizens.
These proposals opened the door to direct promotion by pharmaceutical firms, which appears to us as nonsensical in terms of responding to patients' actual needs.
This operation offers no benefit either to citizens or to Member States.
It signified, on the contrary, additional bureaucracy, an increase in expenses, and causing patients to take risks.
It is for these reasons that we initially presented a motion to reject these texts, thereby requesting that the Commission reconsider its approach.

This approach, also adopted by my colleague Karl Schilter from the Greens group, has enabled our rapporteur, Mr. Fechner, whom I commend, to undertake a significant revision of the Commission’s proposals.

Concurrently, we had submitted some sixty amendments aimed at further protecting the health of our citizens and facilitating patient access to independent, comparative information tailored to individual needs.

The adoption of these amendments in the environmental affairs committee has enabled greater emphasis to be placed on patients’ rights to information, rather than making the provision of information an option for pharmaceutical industries.

In light of the compromise amendments obtained, we have decided to withdraw our proposal to reject the texts, as the substance of the text has evolved in a positive direction over the past few months.
The revised draft report has managed to offset the European Commission’s initial proposals.

However, we will continue to refuse that healthcare professionals be exploited to distribute to their patients brochures and information provided by pharmaceutical companies without any oversight from health authorities.
Similarly, we will oppose the authorization of industrial information campaigns, particularly concerning vaccination.
Information cannot freely come from pharmaceutical companies.

Experience shows that we must be very vigilant, and indeed, I conclude, that what happened with the Mediator drug demonstrates how vigilant we must be and ensure that this point of equilibrium, as we have sought it with this draft report…

Thank you, Mr. President, Madam the Commissioner, Madam the Minister. Unity and realism will be emphasized, at least that is my hope, during tomorrow's vote on our resolution concerning this 16th conference of parties on climate change.

I hope that our designated commissioner will be able to champion the pragmatic goals we will need to achieve collectively, but also uphold the indispensable conditions stipulated by Europe, which is associated with it.
In these negotiations, we must also not lose sight of the legitimate expectations of fairness held by our citizens and our industries.
It is the world that must combat climate change, and not Europe alone.
Thus, recognizing the importance of intellectual property that is insufficiently protected will be essential.
Green technologies must benefit the greatest number, but we must not, for that reason, devalue our current and future knowledge, even in this essential fight against climate change.

Similarly, requesting common methods for calculating emissions, as well as the verification and publication of data, so that all emitting industries are subject to the same standards, appears to be a perfectly legitimate request and not a bargaining tactic.
Finally, more controversially—and my colleague raised this just now—the shortcomings of the current system of clean development mechanisms will also need to be addressed.
Dear colleagues, we are all too well aware, with regret, that the true negotiating power does not reside with the European Parliament.

But the desire of many Members of the European Parliament, including myself, to work and contribute to a positive outcome of this conference must be encouraged, not neglected, as we have perhaps felt these past few days.
If Europe wishes to be strong within international dialogues, it must be so for all its legislators.
Thank you, Madam President. The European Union frequently presents economic partnership agreements as an opportunity for African countries.
Does she also despair at not seeing these agreements signed as quickly as possible?
But the question that concerns us is why these countries are not rushing to sign agreements that would be so advantageous to them.
Clearly, assessments diverge regarding the quality of these agreements. And as long as these divergences of assessment persist, ACP countries will be reluctant to sign them.
Would it not be appropriate to further the dialogue and understanding by listening to the concerns and expectations of ACP countries?
These individuals wish to discuss development strategy, whereas Europe often responds only with market liberalization.
It is this listening that is required by the ACP-EU Parliamentary Assembly.
I believe that other European bodies should proceed in the same manner if we are to build a genuine strategic partnership between Africa and the European Union.
Thank you. Christians are undoubtedly among the most persecuted religious groups in the world.

In the Middle East, they are perceived by certain extremist groups as, and I quote, “legitimate targets.” And the objective is their simple and complete departure from this region—a region that saw the birth of Christianity and in which their historical presence is necessary for a certain balance.
The events at Baghdad Cathedral are only the culmination of a situation we have passively observed for far too long.
The European Union, as a global actor and trading partner of numerous countries in this region, has a responsibility to express its strong indignation in light of the situation.
Discriminations, whatever their form, cannot be tolerated.
Democracy will not be victorious in this region until the most fundamental human rights, such as freedom of religion, are respected.
Colleagues, we are all concerned by the serious crisis currently unfolding in Côte d'Ivoire.

It is evident that the constitutional council of this country’s decision to challenge, in violation of the electoral code, the election results officially proclaimed by the Independent Electoral Commission is unanimously condemned by the international community.

The European Union, the UN, the African Union, the Parliamentary Assembly of the ACP, EU-ACP Partnership, Coas, and soon, certainly, the European Parliament are demanding respect for the official proclamation.

results of the elections and the installation of the new President of the Republic, as recognized by the Independent Electoral Commission. The Independent Electoral Commission, which, I recall, is an entity validated by the UN.
All political groups in the European Parliament have expressed, in a joint statement, their agreement on these essential points.

They also called for curtailing any escalation of tensions within the country that could lead to civil war, which would be a human, social, and economic disaster for Côte d'Ivoire – something that must, of course, be avoided at all costs.

Thank you, Madam President. I also wanted to thank our four rapporteurs, who have done remarkable work and have brought a significant added value from the European Parliament to the texts initially proposed by the Commission.
The citizen initiative that we, at the EPP, are preparing to vote for with enthusiasm represents a significant advancement of the Lisbon Treaty.
Let us not be deceived; this instrument can truly transform the European political landscape. Provided it is used with both responsibility and boldness. I repeat, responsibility and boldness.
it can contribute to bringing European citizens directly into the European political debate.

it can contribute to fostering a European public opinion, that is, men and women who are citizens of Europe, who debate together, who take a stance together, and who unite on genuinely European issues.
But let us not disappoint our fellow citizens.
Let us urge our Member States to swiftly implement the necessary measures where required. Let us not disappoint our citizens; it concerns the strengthening of European democracy. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. I, too, like several of our colleagues, wished to address the issue of the persecution of Christians worldwide, particularly Christians in the East.
We need not reiterate the horrific acts recently committed.
I would like to reiterate this, as well as to defend Christians in the East as throughout the world, to advocate for religious freedom, the diversity of
It is advocating for freedom, democracy, and human rights, which are values at the heart of the European project and which are, of course, as we are all convinced here, universal values.
It is truly time now, beyond the indignation, the emotion, the solemn condemnations, of course, it is truly time now to move from words to action.
Therefore, I earnestly call upon the authorities of the European Union, the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, but also all our governing bodies, the foreign ministers,
to implement precise measures, to establish a precise, concrete action plan to make respect for religious diversity and the fight against all forms of religious persecution a priority. Thank you.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, Madam the High Representative, we are all in agreement that the situation in the Sahel region has deteriorated considerably.
And allowing a lawless zone to take root at the gates of Europe is a danger that we must resolutely and without delay combat.
Extremist groups are proliferating and threatening the lives of civilian populations.
In turn, I lament the loss of human lives and the hostage-takings and am concerned for the European nationals present.
Until now, Morocco has been a bulwark against all forms of trafficking originating from the Sahel.
Alternatively, drug, arms, or human traffickers are now circumventing Morocco by passing through Mauritania to the Canary Islands and then towards the European Union.
It is, it seems to me, the responsibility of the European Union to act to assist these States in bringing these threats to an end.
The security of Europe is at stake on our territory, but also in its immediate neighborhood.
It is time for us to act, and I ask the Commission and the Council to implement an action plan to help restore security in the Sahel.
I join the expressions of sympathy and support that have already been conveyed to the Tunisian and Egyptian peoples.
It represents a symbol of hope for all defenders of freedom.
A thought also for the victims.

I would now like to state that the European Union, which, it has been said, has distinguished itself by its lack of reaction, must indeed stand alongside the Tunisian and Egyptian peoples to assist them in successfully implementing their countries’ openness to reform and in establishing democracy.

The European Union has decided to support Tunisian leaders in undertaking a peaceful transition, preparing for the organization of upcoming elections to secure freedom and enable the Tunisian people to find prosperity through development and social peace, an economy that will allow young people to find employment.

I would conclude by saying that the Union for the Mediterranean faces a significant challenge because the Jasmine Revolution triggered a wave across all the states of the Maghreb, the Near East, and the Middle East.
She must implement a robust strategy toward these countries.

But caution, in the face of this legitimate democratic movement, Europe must find a balance between non-interference in internal affairs, support for the legitimate aspirations of peoples, and stability.
Commissioner, my colleagues have repeatedly pointed out,

At a time when Europe is reflecting on a common strategy for its supply of raw materials, and particularly rare earth elements, we cannot neglect the immense potential represented by the intelligent valorization of our waste.

Strengthen European standards to improve the functioning of collection systems. Address issues of leakage or illegal export of these materials. Furthermore, increasing our collection targets must also be incorporated into the body of this legislation.
Let us not forget the principal actor in the success or failure of this regulation: the consumer.
Citizen empowerment is crucial. If we want to implement effective legislation,
And to that end, my dear Karl Heinz, the eco-contribution, among other systems, has proven to be a most relevant tool.

Producers of electrical and electronic equipment must, of course, become more involved in the collection and recycling system, but the citizen cannot be absolved of responsibility for the waste they generate.
Our citizens must be actors and not spectators in European environmental policy.
Thank you, Madam President, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. I would first like to echo the remark just made by Ms. McGuinness concerning the essential link between food security and agriculture.
The subject that concerns us is the increase in food prices, with the consequences it can have for a number of populations worldwide, but also in Europe.
I would first like to try and share an observation.
The trend of increasing agricultural prices and agricultural commodities is, in my view, a lasting one that will endure for three essential reasons: global demographic evolution and price increases.

of the global population. Second element, the fact that we have entered, with climate warming, a period of climatic hazards that pose a problem, whether it be drought, whether it be floods. And the third point, because the world is also developing
With new emerging countries, consumption levels are increasing.
Therefore, the tension on agricultural markets and agricultural commodities is a significant trend.
It is exacerbated by price volatility. And price volatility is a consequence of the financialization of the global economy.
And it is on this very matter that we must also address, if we want to resolve both the agricultural question and the food question.

And to that end, what the commissioner said is important. There are two elements. Yes, transparency regarding inventories is needed. But a public policy on inventories is also required, both in Europe and a management of inventories at a global scale, particularly at the level of the UN.

And secondly, there needs to be regulation of financial markets and financial speculation, particularly in refusing to allow speculative volumes to become disconnected from the physical quantities being traded on those markets.

We cannot accept that on the issue of food, speculators come to speculate without taking into account the consequences this may have, since it concerns the world's food and humanity. And I conclude by saying
This leads to two major consequences. We need a strong European policy, and we strategically reaffirm Europe's commitment to being a global food and agricultural actor.
Secondly, we need to change our development policy to ensure that, globally—and Europe is an actor in this—we reinvest in agriculture, because we will need all forms of agriculture to feed the world.
Madam President, Commissioner, as in 2008, the price of agricultural commodities is soaring on global markets,
We are only at 3% of the 2008 level.
The decline in production in certain traditional exporting regions due to climate change, the diversion of grains for biofuel production, and speculation

Financial factors that have accentuated the upward effects are responsible for this situation, as demonstrated by the reports of the IMF, the French authorities, and as stated by the Commission as well.
The consequences of this new food crisis are severely impacting the 1.2 billion people worldwide living below the $1.50 threshold.
Since October, an additional 44 million people have joined those living below the poverty line.
Just two days before the G20 meeting, what is Europe waiting for to take measures similar to those passed in the United States?
Since January 13, 2011, the U.S. administration has required the limitation and transparency of positions taken by financial institutions in agricultural commodity markets.
It is taking the first step to counter the appetites of speculators.
The impact is dramatic for European livestock farmers as well.
They are no longer able to feed their animals.
Hundreds of farms are failing.
Five years ago, wheat was worth 100 euros per tonne. Today, it is trading at nearly 300 euros.
The situation has therefore changed completely.
The Commission demands that farmers adapt to market signals. It would do well today to follow its own advice.
Faced with this crisis, the European Union cannot wait until 2014 to find solutions.
We must confront the crisis, and I propose three concrete actions.
Firstly, the creation of stocks in cereal-producing countries to make them available to livestock farmers at subsidized prices immediately.
Secondly, the indexing of meat prices paid to livestock farmers on the evolution of feed prices for livestock.
Thirdly, for 2011, a mechanism for transferring a portion of the subsidies intended to support cereals to animal production. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. Are we ready in Europe to face a pandemic?
The answer is yes, but there's a caveat.
The 2009-2010 H1N1 influenza episode demonstrated that each Member State reacted independently, lacking both coherence and solidarity.

As a fictitious rapporteur on this matter, I believe these observations needed to be made, but more importantly, one needed to go further, to be constructive, concrete for our citizens, who, it must be said—and this is what I find most regrettable—have likely lost some trust in public health messaging.

Ms. Rivasi’s report, which will be voted on tomorrow, takes into consideration these fundamental priorities, including, among others, the systematic strengthening of cooperation between Member States, improved coordination with the
European health institutions, a clarification of the roles of European structures for health risk management, an evaluation of vaccination strategies and communication implemented in Member States.
It is therefore a good report; I congratulate the rapporteur. It is, of course, essential that it not remain a dead letter.
It is the responsibility of our Member States who retain the essential competencies in the matter. It is therefore a genuine responsibility to take toward our citizens.

Thank you, Mr. President. It is now my turn to express my profound emotion following the cowardly assassination on March 2nd last of the Pakistani Minister in charge of Christian minority affairs, Mr. Bhatti.
This act of terrorist violence follows numerous other assassinations of courageous, tolerant Pakistanis, lovers of human rights, human rights defenders, and women's rights advocates, I must say.

Once again, we urgently call on the Pakistani government to shed full light on this cowardly assassination and to effectively, truly effectively, ensure the protection of individuals threatened by fanatical religious extremists.
And I think, of course, first and foremost, but not exclusively, of Ms. Sherry Raymond.
And I also wanted, once again, with force, to ask all competent institutions of the European Union to include in the negotiations aiming to
to prepare future cooperation agreements, notably the cooperation agreement between the EU and Pakistan, including a clause on respect for freedom of religion and respect for human rights. Thank you.
Mr. President, for your reference, with the crisis and the bursting of the real estate and credit bubble, the Irish State had to intervene to support the banks.
The Irish public deficit and cumulative budgetary balance of central, local, and particularly social security administrations were estimated at 32% of GDP in 2010.

If the Irish government, which can scarcely refinance itself on the markets, wishes to access loans from the European Stability Mechanism and the European Financial Stability Facility, it will have to meet obligations of a social and fiscal nature, even though these areas fall under the principle of subsidiarity.
In our view, this is not contradictory.
As a physician, I would say that in the case of fever, it is pointless to prescribe antipyretics blindly without seeking to treat the underlying cause.
Should these funds be allocated, it falls to that State to undertake a financial restructuring in order to bridge its excessive deficit and rectify previous errors.
This austerity plan is projected to increase GDP by 10% over the next four years.

Just as an individual, a bank without interfering in their life and private management will condition a personal loan on a solvency guarantee. Similarly, the European Union can lend to Ireland on the basis of consolidated solvency.
Without interfering in its private management, the bank will encourage the individual to negotiate, for example, a salary increase or to borrow elsewhere.

It is in this way that, while respecting the principle of subsidiarity, the European Union, based on a memorandum established with the IMF, considers that this solvency requires a reduction in the statutory minimum wage and an adjustment of pensions, without absolving itself of fiscal measures.
It is up to Ireland to choose whether or not to implement these measures.

It is not an opening for European Union interference in areas of subsidiarity, which would, for example, dangerously impose a European minimum wage, but a protection of the stability of the euro zone through a process of mutual guarantee.

It is, of course, appropriate to assist Ireland as are other countries facing difficulty, which also protects us, but not at any price, particularly that of seeing a state unable to repay its debts in the long term, thereby weakening its citizens and those of the entire European Union.

Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, the eruption of the Icelandic volcano last April, as many of us have just stated, provided a painful illustration of the fragmentation and ineffectiveness of European airspace.
And each of us in this chamber has been directly affected.
and 5 million of our fellow citizens found themselves stranded without a viable alternative means of transportation.
And a year after this exceptional event, new European measures are still awaited.

A first crisis simulation exercise, as you mentioned, Mr. Commissioner, related to volcanic ash, is indeed scheduled for April 13th and 14th, coordinated by Eurocontrol of the ICAO and IATA, but it is essential that EASA assume genuine leadership for the coordination of security measures at the European level.
It is certain that the information provided by the VACs in London and Toulouse must be refined using more modern technological means.

These data, as was observed last April, can nevertheless be contradictory and may lead each Member State to make decisions concerning the closure of their airspace, less motivated by information than by emotion.
In this context, the role of the AESA is essential for proposing a harmonized interpretation of this data, as well as for ensuring the centralization and proper dissemination of information.
Beyond the provision of VAC information, EASA must establish a mechanism for collecting available data, closely associating Member States, airlines, and their pilots.
This centralization of information and coordination of all stakeholders will prevent the chaos and inconsistencies we witnessed last year.
I therefore expect the Commission to be able, with the AESA, to present concrete proposals rapidly that will be fully integrated into the realization of the Single European Sky.
President, esteemed colleagues, this text is important.
It is not a revolution. We cannot say that everything was wrong before and that everything is perfect now.
Nevertheless, it presents a number of major advances at this provisional stage of our work.
The main concerns, in my opinion, relate to better regulation of distance selling, and particularly online. And that is chapter 3. Because consumer rights must be strengthened in this area.
E-commerce is highly beneficial. It expands consumer choice, allows them to obtain the lowest prices, and also enables small and medium-sized enterprises and artisans to find new markets.
To progress in this field, it had to be done in a truly European way, that is, on a few highly targeted points, by establishing a complete harmonization of everyone's rights and obligations.
Very concretely, an Italian client purchasing from a Belgian or German website needed to know that they would now benefit from the same rights, the same protection.
This is what this directive will make possible.
This means that its withdrawal period will extend to 14 days throughout the European Union.
That means he will immediately know the total amount he has to pay, without fear of an unpleasant surprise afterward.
That means that with a double click, it will correctly validate its order.
Of course, all of this will disrupt certain established practices.
In many states, there are subtleties in national law that each is convinced are fundamental, whereas sometimes they are not even to be found in neighboring countries.
But living together in Europe means learning to adjust one’s habits somewhat in the service of the common and general interest.
Let us be clear: this text will still need to be improved, and we will need to do so in the coming weeks, with the Council and with the Commission.
And I appreciated the openings that have just been made in this regard.
But we have already done substantial work, thanks to our rapporteur Andréa Schwab, whom I warmly thank.
But the true fruit of this work is above all the fact that the amendments will be voted on tomorrow by all political groups.
Consumer confidence in the EU's internal market is very fragile.
This political unanimity was required to preserve it and to hope to strengthen it.
At point number 7, after the first paragraph, a first consideration, to guarantee respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, particularly the freedom of the individual.
freedom of speech and assembly and the right to demonstrate peacefully and to listen to and consider the legitimate demands of protesters and to ensure their safety.

Thank you, Madam President, dear colleagues, Commissioner. The Open Skies agreement between Europe and the United States is an advancement, but it is only a step. A step that places Europe before a dilemma.
The transport committee and the committee itself have highlighted this.
Either we accept an agreement that disadvantages European businesses, or we suspend the agreement and risk losing the benefits accrued since 2008.
Let me then draw a parallel with the licenses of private and professional pilots, a text that will be discussed before summer. Because the pilots among whom I count myself are facing a dilemma.
The European Union Aviation Safety Agency, seeking to harmonise licences across the European territory, will do so at the expense of 80,000 to 90,000 general aviation pilots.
directly concerned, some holding only a single U.S. license, and to the detriment, and this is important, of companies and jobs linked to this activity.
