I wish to draw your attention to this project, which lacks any security justification.
There are 31 times fewer accidents among license holders of American origin.

The objectives of the foundational regulatory text 216-2008 allow for the anticipation of recognition and equivalence of licenses, for which there appears to be no benefit in awaiting hypothetical agreements postponed to 2014.

Therefore, I propose a very open sky agreement and even invite you to accompany me when I sometimes come to Parliament myself, piloting, to demonstrate to you that an American pilot's license is entirely safe.
Thank you, Madam President. At this stage of our debate, I will inevitably be led to repeat or reinforce certain points that have already been made.

But I also wanted to say that, like several of my colleagues, the problems we are facing, the problems that the entire European Union is currently facing, cannot be resolved by any Member State alone.
No Member State should find itself alone facing the challenges confronting it and, in my view, confronting the entire European Union.
It is therefore truly to the capacity of the European Union to organize itself and to respond collectively, in a spirit of solidarity, that I am calling.
I believe that the time has truly come now to lay the groundwork for a genuine European policy on immigration and asylum.
More than a year ago, a European asylum and immigration pact was adopted.
The time has now come, I think, to delineate it very concretely.
We certainly heard Madame the Commissioner, we heard a number of recommendations she was making.
I wanted to revisit this and strongly endorse several of his proposals.
Yes, it is essential to strengthen the resources of the Frontex agency.

It is necessary to strengthen the human resources, the material resources, and the financial resources of the Frontex agency, and to enable it to more robustly support Operation Hermes and Operation Poseidon.
Yes, additional financial resources are needed for Member States that are, I would say, first and foremost, facing the accentuated migratory flows we are experiencing today.
and this will be the financial expression of our solidarity.
Yes, it is necessary to forge closer relationships of cooperation with the states of the southern Mediterranean shore, to accompany them, of course, to assist them, to find instruments.
The Commissioner was referencing, I believe she went to Tunisia to discuss it, mobility partnerships.
Indeed, these instruments must be strengthened in a spirit of responsibility, in a spirit of solidarity, but also in a spirit of precision and concreteness. Thank you.

Mr. Commissioner, you are undoubtedly aware that the most intense discussions we have had here concerning your communication pertain to the role of public services, services of general economic interest, within the single market and their legislative transposition.
We have arrived at a compromise formulation that invites you to go beyond your proposal 25, and we ask you to move beyond a mere proposal.

communications that would fail to meet the expectations and needs of stakeholders – actors, users, and all stakeholders in public services – and that would also fall short of the objectives you otherwise articulate.
The European Union must deliver a clear and unambiguous message regarding public services.
For this, we must create a positive legal framework, either in the form of a regulation or a directive.
The Treaty of Lisbon provides us with its legal foundations.
It is now up to you to translate them into legislative proposals.
I believe the Parliament is ready to follow you in this direction.
Thank you, Mr. President. Well, firstly, congratulations to all the rapporteurs for their monumental work on this discharge. And I also welcome the Council’s presence for this debate.
The European Parliament's seat in Strasbourg is a matter of European identity and is not solely an economic issue.

I am speaking today in this hemicycle on the occasion of the debate on the 2009 discharge, because the symbol of Franco-German reconciliation is being treated by some members of the joint Mann budgetary control committee as a mere means of cutting costs.
The question of parliamentary spending also interests me.
On this matter, I propose holding the group weeks in Strasbourg rather than in Brussels. This would allow us to better utilize our Parliament building in Strasbourg.
And since we want to make savings, I propose other measures. For example, eliminating Friday overtime for our colleagues. Also, the elimination of overtime for journalists.
Europe is attractive enough that it is not necessary to give journalists a per diem.

Let us not hide behind the budgetary argument to take ownership of a significant issue that extends beyond the scope of budgetary oversight, even though I commend the important work of Villeux, our rapporteur, regarding this discharge.
Finally, since we are discussing economics, I also wish that we would rationalize and cleanse the system of compensation for sponsored visitor groups.

I do not find it very moral, and it gives a very poor image of our institution, that the group leader be reimbursed in cash, in specie, on the day of the visit, without any work being done, any verification of what the group has spent.
Occasionally, the allocated sum, I must bring to your attention, exceeds the amount of actual expenditures.

It would be logical for groups to submit a quotation in advance to the visitor services department, to receive an advance payment from Parliament against expenses, and that payment should be made to a bank account, and the balance paid upon presentation of invoices actually paid, with a ceiling, of course. Thank you.
Thank you, Madam President. I address the Commission, my colleagues, and I acknowledge the presence of the Council.
The question that arises today stems from the 2011 management of the Schengen Area.

This is no longer the space of the five member states of the 1980s; it is, on the contrary, a space that has continually expanded in recent years and now comprises 25 states, three of which are non-members of the European Union.
As with all European policies, Schengen cooperation must therefore adapt to the reality it encompasses today, a reality that is no longer the same as it was ten years ago.

It is in this sense that the proposals of the Italian and French governments, and the pragmatic and necessary responses provided today by the Commission in its communication on immigration, should be read.
Mutual trust between the States party to the Schengen Area is, of course, the cornerstone of Schengen cooperation.
But this trust rests on reciprocal obligations.
If one of the parties fails to meet its obligations and creates drafts, the entire system becomes faulty.
It must therefore be possible for other States to respond to this failure by temporarily and strictly regulated control of these borders.
In doing so, these failing states will be clearly invited to better control their external borders.

Furthermore, as presented by the Commission, these measures would fully respect the spirit of Schengen, insofar as these controls would be reintroduced as a last resort and the decision would be made at the European level and not intergovernmentally.
Such measures will be intrinsically linked to the entirety of the long-term measures contemplated within the framework of a common migration policy.
It is notably essential to strengthen Frontex, to provide for greater solidarity—I conclude—to support the States located at the external borders.
The situation the Mediterranean has experienced in recent years only highlights a shortcoming of Schengen.
Just two minutes, Madam President. Over a few weeks, migrants from countries bordering the Mediterranean have represented a notable percentage of annual French immigration.
This acquisition is not static, but must instead evolve.

I hope that these proposals will be swiftly adopted to guarantee the public a better management of our Schengen area and, in doing so, to ensure the security of our common external borders. Thank you.
The European Union has finally imposed sanctions against Syria.
But unfortunately, she appears to be doing so with a trembling hand, carefully avoiding questioning the head of the Syrian regime.
This lack of determination and clarity is obviously interpreted by the protesters as a form of abandonment and by the authorities as an indulgence that allows them to intensify the
repression. A repression so cruel that one cannot even imagine that at the same moment Syria could be elected to sit on the Human Rights Council of the organization of
Even today, Syrian authorities are denying the United Nations observers access to the city of Deira, the scene of terrible violence against defenseless civilians.

Syria’s presence at the Human Rights Council would be an insult to the victims and their families, an encouragement for the regime to use brute force against its people, in disregard, precisely, of the values that the Human Rights Council should safeguard.
So, Madam High Representative, what diplomatic options are you considering to avert such a disaster?

Madame Mathieu, a minute and a half. Thank you, Mr. President, Madam the Commissioner, dear colleagues. I would first like to congratulate my colleague Carlos Coelho, who has produced a masterwork on this report, and God knows that it was very complicated.
Bulgaria and Romania have made considerable efforts to strengthen the control of their borders, and they have succeeded.
Whether concerning police and judicial cooperation, data protection, visa policy, and the control of air, maritime, or land borders, the most recent assessments are very clear.
All technical criteria are met.
We can only observe this state of affairs.
Bulgaria and Romania are now able to implement the Schengen acquis both technically and in terms of personnel.
Moreover, while no impediment currently prevents this expansion of the Schengen Area, we note that a number of recommendations have been addressed to these two countries.

I hope that these recommendations will be strictly monitored, particularly with regard to the borders between Bulgaria, Greece, and Turkey, because, as you know, mutual trust between Schengen states rests on the full respect by those states of their reciprocal obligations.
If one of the parties fails to meet its obligations and creates drafts, the entire system becomes faulty.
I earnestly hope that an agreement will be reached within the Council to welcome these two countries into the select circles formed by the Schengen States.
and we will all measure, within this hemicycle, the impact of this type of decision on the citizens concerned.
Well done again to Mr. Coelho for his report. Thank you, Mr. President.
Thank you, Mr. President. In its Europe 2020 strategy, the European Union has set itself the objective of making our economy greener and our transport systems more modern.
All European institutions have strongly supported this objective, including almost all Member States and our Parliament.
In this context, it is therefore regrettable that, since 2008, several Member States have sought to strip the new eurovignette directive proposal of its substance and to obstruct its progress.

Today, however, thanks to the tenacity of our rapporteur—and I would like to acknowledge Saïd El Khadraoui here—thanks to his tenacity and that of the shadow rapporteurs, in their negotiations with the Council, we finally have a compromise before us.

Indeed, this text is considerably less ambitious than the initial proposal, but it will, for the first time, put into practice the polluter-pays principle and internalize external costs of transportation, such as noise or CO2 emissions.

To ensure that this Eurovignette is not merely a tax, but genuinely contributes to the improvement of transportation in Europe, Member States are also incentivized to reinvest the collected funds in the modernization of transport modes.
The Parliament also succeeded in securing concrete advancements regarding the interoperability of toll systems, as well as stronger incentives for the use of cleaner heavy goods vehicles.

To remain consistent with the objectives set by our institution, I sincerely hope that we can adopt this compromise proposed in the second reading and thus pave the way for a more sustainable transport policy. Thank you.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, yes, I agree that alongside liberty and fraternity, there must be equality for farmers and for countries that have joined us, including those from Eastern Europe.
Yes, I agree with you.
I believe we have made a significant step forward with this report.
It wasn’t easy at the outset, and we were rather in a confrontational situation, but we arrived at a consensus, and that's what matters most.
This consensus allows for the protection of the overall project, and I believe that is the great merit of the European Parliament.
We have succeeded in this endeavor, and it was not easy. I therefore thank the rapporteur, Mr. Morciedes, and all the parliamentarians.
First step.
In this text, we reaffirm the necessity of equality, justice, and fairness both among producers and between territories, and I believe that this is important.
We stated very clearly and confirmed the maintenance and development of small farms, the consideration of small farms, which is essential for the quality and biodiversity of territories.
I believe that it was also fundamental.
The introduction of the concept of making agriculture agronomic, of turning the page on industrial, productivity-focused agriculture, has been enshrined in the texts.
Now, it will be necessary to put this into effect. It is a condition for making agriculture possible for future generations.
It is not an ideological question.
Ultimately, today, our concern is that, indeed, there are threats to the budget.
It will be necessary to respond to it clearly.

Now, what we are expecting is that, indeed, we enter the second phase, which is clearly the legislative debate. Because beyond the texts, the broad intentions, it is within the legislative debate that we will truly see where we are headed. And that is what we are expecting, naturally, now.
I would still like to conclude by voicing my outrage at Germany’s stance, which has led to a reduction of 5 in food aid for the poorest in Europe.
it was factored into the CAP budget.
I want us to rediscover the means of helping the most vulnerable. There are 80 million European citizens who do not eat sufficiently.

Thank you, Mr. President. While the European Parliament can certainly take pride in some notable advances in economic governance, I urge my colleagues to exercise humility, for we are dancing on the edge of an abyss.
Let us be acutely aware of two things.
The first point is that the European Parliament remained unheard during the Greek crisis.
While we are normally so quick to react to all sorts of events with resolutions worldwide, this existential crisis seems to leave us speechless.
I deeply regret that we were unable to send a strong, concrete, simple message to the Greeks, to the governments of the Member States, to European citizens.
The second observation concerns the scope of this package.
By voting for what I wish, these six directives and the regulations, we will certainly enable the euro area to take another step forward.
a step—I say, nothing more—toward a discipline that has been so lacking to us, a step that will demonstrate its usefulness in the future.

But one need only observe the heated debates surrounding the overturned qualified majority to measure the distance we still have to travel. When it should be a matter of rules and automatic sanctions.
The mechanism of the reverse qualified majority continues to act on some like a scarecrow.
We must, nonetheless, remain steadfast on the principle.
On a strictly political level, I regret that the benches of the left continue to reject principles of sound budgetary management despite all evidence.
Yes, deficit and sustainable growth are antonymous.
Yes, states must also manage their budgets like responsible heads of households, but not through stimulus spending. It is a short-term palliative, but never a sustainable solution.
As the coming weeks promise to be crucial, the task at hand is to refound an economic union.
This morning, we voted on a very important text for the advancement of consumer protection in Europe, after three years of work.
It rightly focuses on online purchases that may, in 20 years, represent 25% of all commerce in Europe, which is quite considerable.
These purchases will be transborder in particular.
They will allow consumers to broaden their choices and also to pay considerably less.
This represents a genuine advancement.
For SMEs, and for all artisans, it also represents a very important opportunity to expand their markets.

Among the key advancements, I would just like to mention two. The cancellation period, which extends to 14 days, and the recapitalization of all information and the total price to be paid before pressing the final button that confirms the order.

Finally, I am proud, within the context of these explanations of vote, to say that I, but the entire group of our colleagues, voted unanimously across political groups, because on such a subject, it was not polemic that we needed, but evidently electoral consensus.
and we obtained it.

Mathieu Deminut. Welcome, Commissioner. Madam President, Madam, and Commissioners, I would first like to commend the efforts of our colleague Carlos Coelho on this very difficult dossier, which required considerable technical expertise, a great deal of work, and thorough knowledge of the matter.
The control of our shared territory and our European borders is one of the most significant challenges we must address, and technological tools are more than ever at the service of this endeavor.
Indeed, in recent years, we have witnessed an unprecedented development of European databases and the exchange of personal data.
What some describe as a “digital tsunami” should certainly be confirmed in the years to come.
The SIS, VIS, and Rodax are all essential instruments today for ensuring the security of our European citizens.
Ensuring the sound operational management of these databases is therefore a major issue to which it is our responsibility to provide an effective response.

This response is, of course, highly delicate, and Carlos Coelho faced numerous legal, institutional, budgetary, political, and technical obstacles, yet he nonetheless produced a balanced text that satisfies all stakeholders.
The creation of this network agency appears, indeed, to be the best solution for ensuring the internal security of Member States.
No other existing institution or agency could currently assume responsibility for the proper management of these information systems.

It will enable the improvement of existing information systems management, it will offer greater synergy between these databases, and will also allow for the integration of instruments that will be adopted in the future.
One of the very delicate questions that arose in this case concerned the location of the agency. Where should it be established?
Estonia and France are the only two countries that have bid to host it.

France already hosts the Schengen Information System in Strasbourg, the operational management and administration of which it has ensured since 1995. Consequently, it possesses complete technical mastery of it.
Following the conclusions of the December 2003 European Council, which prioritized the new Member States, Estonia also wished to receive the seat of this future agency.

It seems to me that the agreement reached is very good. A sort of allocation of responsibilities, I conclude, Madam President, has occurred through the transfer of the Agency's headquarters to Tallinn, where governance, strategy, and program design tasks will be carried out.
The development and deployment of the systems will take place in Strasbourg.
The cost-effectiveness analysis is quite balanced, and this comprehension solution does not challenge the centralized management of IT systems in any way. Thank you, Madam President.
The horizontal social clause and Article 14 of the Treaty of Lisbon guarantee social rights in a binding manner, notably the right to access essential services.
It is time to demonstrate to European citizens that the social Europe is underway.

Therefore, it is necessary to give our social achievements the place they deserve within Community law, by recognizing the specific characteristics of Services of General Interest (SGIs) in relation to competition rules, bearing in mind that these services have a strong local base and are underpinned by actors from the social economy.

Mr. De Rosa’s report provides an opportunity to reaffirm the simple yet powerful and meaningful principles of equality, universality, and access to collectively organized services, which are drivers of well-being and social progress.
Madam Commissioner, you said it was time to move to specifics.
Yes, it is time to move to specifics. Therefore, I propose in this debate that we genuinely support a European legislative instrument for social services.
I therefore invite you to vote for the alternative resolution submitted by the Green group.
Thank you, Mr. President. Debates concerning GMOs must unequivocally rest on irrefutable arguments, both scientific and legal.
Legally, member states wishing to restrict or prohibit GMOs within their territory required arguments as varied as they were robust.
The rapporteur has broadened the margin of my flat bémol nonetheless.
Regarding health, it's a bit more about health.
which, from a scientific perspective, must also be irrefutable.
The Council has repeatedly challenged the scientific assessments of EFSA, which have consistently been positive regarding GMOs, in contrast to national scientific assessments.

To restore confidence, shouldn't we, Mr. Commissioner, first and foremost simply apply the existing legislation that aims to provide considerable scientific guarantees, particularly in terms of long-term impact assessment?
Why have the Council’s recommendations from October 2008 remained unimplemented?
Thank you, Madam President, Madam Commissioner. First and foremost, I would like to thank our colleague Simon Buzitil for the remarkable work he has done.
These reflections have enriched the initial proposal, and we can only commend them for it.
This report outlines an agency operating at an amplified scale, more closely aligned with the missions assigned to it.
Recent events have demonstrated the necessity of closer cooperation between the European Union, its Member States, and the support of a robust agency.
Frontex finally receives the resources to fulfill its missions.
By being able to acquire or rent its own equipment and by benefiting from the services of its own border guards, it becomes more independent and highly effective.
New tasks have also been assigned to him, such as organizing voluntary returns and processing personal data, so that we can combat transnational crime while protecting fundamental rights.
This expansion of Frontex's field of competence enables us to consider and address migration issues through a comprehensive approach, and to move beyond a purely mechanical management of borders.
I approve the possibility of exchanging personal data with other European agencies, notably Europol.
Finally, the human dimension has taken its rightful place in this report.
A strong recognition of human rights is ensured by the proposal to establish a consultative council within the agency.

I can only commend this comprehensive proposal, which represents a step forward towards sound and responsible management of our external borders, in a context where migratory pressures are particularly strong and persistent. I thank you.

Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr. Meyer, and the comments of my colleagues, which were sometimes critical. But this 2010 activity report is finally a wonderful opportunity to discuss the Committee on Petitions, as it remains too little known.
Yet, it is the Commission, having a direct, sometimes physical, link with the citizen, who can witness our debates firsthand.
She possesses undeniable legitimacy within Parliament as well as extensive expertise owing to her direct engagement with citizens.
Indeed, any petitioner may go to Parliament and defend their rights before the petitions committee.
One can also commend the serenity of the debates, despite the painful cases that are often addressed.
This Commission represents Europe as it should be—attentive to the concerns of its citizens and united to find and protect solutions.
Unfortunately, avenues for action and means of influence remain limited, particularly regarding the environmental risk of projects sometimes nearing completion.
But I also see it when it comes to defending specific cases, such as the rights of the family or the rights of the child in the event of divorce.
We will, incidentally, undertake a mission in November on this subject.
I also regret that the national authorities do not always hasten to provide us with all the necessary information.
I would like to thank the European Commission for the research and verification work it carries out, even if it could sometimes go further in the pursuit of truth.
I must also acknowledge the constructive work we are undertaking with the European mediator.
I now appeal to the citizens. Continue to solicit us through petitions as directly elected representatives.
Our role will always be to safeguard your interests in strict compliance with European law.
Madam President, Commissioner, I welcome this resolution on homelessness because it is our responsibility to emphasize its extreme urgency.
We observe first that what was a priority yesterday remains so, and in a yet more pronounced manner today.

The lack of a definition and reliable statistical indicators regarding homelessness should not prevent us from noting, crisis notwithstanding, that the number of people living below the poverty line has risen, according to Eurostat, from 79 million in 2009 to an estimated 84 million in 2011.
Dear colleagues, three years ago, our Parliament, eager to eradicate poverty, asked the Member States to put an end to the problem of tax shopper companies by 2015.
Today, we ourselves are somewhat closer to our objective.
Did the year 2010, dedicated to the fight against poverty, truly enable Member States to address concretely this widespread precariousness, the urgency of which has become permanent?
I genuinely question this, and I deeply regret it.

To conclude, I wish to emphasize the necessity of developing a comprehensive, multisectoral strategy to address homelessness, because, of course, there is poverty and a lack of housing, certainly, but there are also familial issues, health concerns, various addictions, and personal vulnerabilities.
A comprehensive, effective, and ambitious approach is required, one that is tailored, taking into account individuals, the heterogeneous nature of their backgrounds, and their life disruptions.
It is a right, at the very least, from which a significant number of those in precarious situations are deprived.
Thank you, Madam President. In recent years, everyone has said it: the European Union has been struck by unprecedented disasters. And the cities here would take up the entirety of the debate.
I will still mention the AZF explosion, the 10th anniversary of which we commemorated less than a week ago in Toulouse.
A strengthened reaction at the European level, as proposed in Ms. Gardini’s report, represents a genuine opportunity to demonstrate solidarity among our populations.

For several years now, the Union has been striving to make this pooling of our efforts operational. And the time has come to act together and to no longer wait for another catastrophe to strike our territories before drawing lessons from it.
Today, it is a matter of making our material, human, and financial resources available to all, in order to prevent further tragedies from occurring.
Madam Commissioner, earlier you stated that we must anticipate the risks.

And it is truly regrettable that, in this context, the European Commission is considering withdrawing from funding the GMES satellite observation program, which is universally recognized as an essential instrument for the prevention and coordination of responses to disasters.
And I urge the Commission to reconsider this position and to support these flagship programs that give Europe an undeniable added value.
Well, I would like to thank Madame Gardini for her very good report.
I hope that we will adopt it. This will thus pave the way for European solidarity at the service of the citizen. I thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. Commissioner, Minister, the number of people living in poverty and unemployed individuals continues to increase within the European Union.
Over 43 million Europeans are threatened by food poverty.
The situation is critical.
Today, 6 Member States wish to end the food aid program without any replacement solution. Germany, Sweden, Denmark, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, and the Czech Republic.
Certainly, there is a ruling from the Court of Justice, and we must respect it.
However, Commissioner, Parliament questioned you last July at the initiative of our Green group, and you have made pertinent proposals to safeguard the programme.
The Greens are ready to work with you on long-term solutions. But once millions of people depend on this system, we cannot reduce the food aid budget by a factor of four.
The urgency is real.
If no action is taken by the end of the year, food banks will face a shortfall of over €300 million, and there is no guarantee that national governments will be able to step in to fill this gap.
It is therefore a genuine question of solidarity between peoples.
Let us not allow an irresponsible government minority to deprive millions of Europeans of food aid because it is fundamentally a matter of survival.
The fight against poverty and malnutrition also requires a reform of the CAP.
We must fundamentally change our methods of production in order to bring food production closer to populations, particularly the poorest, who are and who have a right to a healthy and balanced diet.
Only a truly sustainable CAP will enable us to ensure that fewer Europeans need food assistance.
The Council must return to reason and allow those in need to access this vital assistance.
I would particularly like to address the future Danish government, which will have the responsibility of ensuring the presidency of the European Union starting in January.
Come to your senses. Does it take riots born of hunger in Europe to realize the urgent need to change our logic?

When it comes to saving banks, the Council found solutions, but when it comes to saving food banks, it’s as if there’s no one left. Parliament made a strong point last time: human beings are more important than finance.
It is high time to reaffirm it.
In any case, we will be very vigilant and will not fail to reiterate our appeal in a constructive manner.
Six Member States hold the fate of 18 million Europeans in need.
six member states claiming to do no more and no less than legal formalism
Legalism is one thing, humanism and political choices are another.
How can we fail to express our anger towards those who remain deaf to the cries of alarm raised by associations aiding the most vulnerable?

And we, the Members of the European Parliament, representatives of all citizens, do we want an Europe where national egoisms dictate policy, paying little heed to the citizens of states facing budgetary difficulties?
There is no question of renationalizing this support.

No. Let us maintain this program, give it a stronger legal basis, but let us not abandon those who, immediately, in 2012, are relying on this assistance during particularly difficult times. I thank you.

Thank you, Mr. President. Commissioner, I will not revisit the cynicism with which the ArcelorMittal group announced the closure of some of its facilities in Europe, and particularly in Belgium, in Liège, ultimately leading to hundreds of direct job losses and jeopardizing several thousand indirect jobs.
As a Liège resident, I share the shock and distress of the 581 workers and their families who have been laid off.
but I am also thinking about the severe restructurings announced by the steel group in France, Germany, and Luxembourg.
The reasons cited? Always the same. Unfavorable prospects for the steel market in Europe, intense competition with imports from China, Korea,
Russia and Brazil, the reduction of the automobile market, and finally the competitiveness gap, for example that of the Liège site, compared to the best factories in Northern Europe.
Alongside this, and despite a difficult 2010, the financial center of the ArcelorMittal Belgium steel group generated a profit of €1,394,000,000.
He paid 0 euro in tax, representing an effective tax rate of 0%.
It is particularly shocking.
Group management is primarily financial, with a stop and go policy implemented across multiple sites.
And the closure of sites is nothing more, in the view of these leaders, than an economic adjustment variable where human considerations are of little importance,
It is no longer acceptable.
You spoke of the regulations, Commissioner?
Wouldn't it be time for the Commission to draft a binding code of social responsibility for multinational corporations?

Six years ago now that our Parliament adopted a report concerning relocations, corporate codes of conduct, the reimbursement of subsidies, and mandatory consultation between companies, trade unions, and public authorities.
Since then, it must be acknowledged that little concrete progress has been made on these various proposals.
So, what does the Commission intend to do about this, and within what timeframe?
If we are to support the competitiveness of businesses and make Europe attractive in terms of economic investment, we must also adopt a legislative framework.
robust European framework to address relocations and restructurings and to ensure full consideration of another capital, human capital.

Finally, with regard to the Liège site, I hope it will be able to benefit from the intervention of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund in order to improve the situation of the laid-off workers. Thank you.

Madam President, dear colleagues, the wave of layoffs hitting workers across Europe must lead us to reflect on the role that we, as political leaders, have to play in the face of multinational corporations that act.

without any social ethics, which implements stock-based layoffs and relocates in order to reduce costs, increase shareholder profits, and appease rating agencies, disregarding social and environmental standards.

In its resolution of 20 September last, concerning the future of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, Parliament clearly expressed its desire to support, above all, employees affected by the negative effects of restructuring.

But we also asked the Commission to ensure consistency between the interventions of the European Microfinance Facility and the European Union’s industrial policy, notably through the use of structural funds.

We have also advocated for improvements in the forthcoming FEMM regulation, so that it does not produce the outcomes it does today regarding multinational corporations, random effects, and ethical considerations—as has been the case with ArcelorMittal and Nokia.
Sir Commissioner, we can no longer continue to consider the issues of structural funds and the Globalisation Adjustment Fund separately without…
to consider the restructuring strategies employed by companies that benefit from them without examining the co-benefit ratio of a policy, I reiterate this...
Thank you, Mr. President. The European mediator conducts investigations into complaints directed against the institutions and bodies of the European Union with skill.

This instrument is both necessary to facilitate free movement, that of our businesses and our citizens, but it is also a formidable guarantee, particularly in the face of critics of the Union, who too often assert that the European Union is nothing more than an uncontrolled bureaucratic machine.
It is clearly nonsense. Europe is doing genuine work on itself, thanks notably to the European mediators.
But allow me to relay an observation that I deeply regret, in which the Commission is under heavy criticism.
There are first the figures. 65% is the actual figure, not 12% of the inquiries opened by the mediator concerning the European Commission.

There are also stakeholders. Numerous companies come to see us to explain their misunderstanding of the Commission, of a European Commission that remains deaf to their requests, particularly concerning access to documents. Similarly, regarding the issue of transparency in decision-making,
Few people enjoy it.
And finally, through personal experience, I must confess that I have sometimes been shocked by the reactions of certain services of the European Commission present on the petitions committee.
You are aware that the European Commission is giving us its position on petitions, a position that we always take into account and which is necessary.

But it occasionally happens to see representatives of the European Commission who refuse to answer a Member of Parliament’s questions or who take refuge in a jargon almost as skillfully as politicians, and wonder about citizens advocating for their cause.

Therefore, I wanted to remind you that Europe must have a human face, that behind the administrative problems identified and resolved by the mediator lie Europeans, relieved to be heard but disappointed by these concerns.
behavior. Citizens then negatively marked by their confrontation with institutions, potentially creating a sentiment of revolt, incomprehension, and ultimately perhaps euroscepticism.
I sincerely hope that these criticisms, and those of the mediator against institutions in general, are heard. Thank you.
Thank you, Madam President. Professional mobility and growth, professional mobility and the competitiveness of our European Union – such are the terms in which the subject of today is framed.

Therefore, we, the PPE group, have offered our support for the report by our colleague Ms. Matt Larkin, a report to whose development we made a significant contribution, and we unequivocally support those who have been affected.

The principal recommendation of this report, to foster greater professional mobility, increased simplification, and enhanced efficiency in the procedures for recognizing professional qualifications, while guaranteeing the safety of patients and the safety of consumers.
but it is in terms of the pathway to growth that the challenge of increased professional mobility arises.
And indeed, the forum for a single market, held in Kraków at the beginning of October, was not mistaken in this regard.

who recalled that Member States must recognize the potential of the internal market to revitalize growth and job creation and must act to eliminate all obstacles to the completion of the internal market.
Similarly, the European Council of 23 October last also set as one of the essential priorities for achieving growth, I quote, “smart, sustainable.”
including the implementation of the 12 priority proposals of the Act for the Single Market, the 12 proposals made by the Commission under which the recognition of professional qualifications.

And we clearly see that it is by increasing professional mobility that we can hope to unlock the growth potential contained within the single market, our single market of 500 million inhabitants, 500 million consumers.

Professional mobility must therefore enable not only to ensure, should we strengthen it, modernize it, and improve the free movement of our fellow citizens within this market, but also to acquire, we hope, additional growth margins.
That is why, and I want to emphasize a practical recommendation, we PPEs, in particular, should offer our support to the implementation of a voluntary professional card.
Thank you, Madam President. I would first like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr. Kaczmarek, for his excellent work.
It is important that, each year, the European Parliament draws up an assessment of the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, as
This Assembly plays a decisive role in strengthening North-South dialogue and in establishing a development policy based on partnership and exchange.
The year 2010 was a productive year for the APP, which met on two occasions, as predecessors have noted, in Spain and the DRC, to exchange information, among other things.
on the impact of climate change in ACP countries, the impact of the global crisis, and also on media freedom and independence and food security.
But in 2010, the APP also dispatched its first election observation mission for that legislature.
I had the honor of co-chairing this mission to Burundi for the presidential elections with my colleague Assarid, a Member of Parliament from Mali.
This election observation mission proved to be a resounding success.

We were able to meet all the political stakeholders involved, and thanks to the dual origin of this delegation—both ACP and European—we embodied a legitimacy distinct from European or African missions.
I invite the APP Secretariat to renew this experience, which enables the implementation of solidarity and the privileged relations that unite the European Union with the ACP countries.
I would like to thank Mr. Dardenne for his report.
Certainly, the crisis is economic and financial, but above all, it is a social crisis for our citizens.
Reducing the number of people living in precarious situations by 20 million by 2020 requires strong measures involving different levels of public authority.

We must, more than ever, uphold the commitments made by the European Union in 2010, during the European Year for Combating Poverty and Social Exclusion, and upon the creation of the European Platform against Poverty and Social Exclusion, to establish a European framework for social and territorial cohesion.

We must ensure the sustainability and optimization of European funds, and in particular the current support program for the most vulnerable, improve social protection, and support local or national initiatives that develop services for the care of children, the elderly, and dependent individuals.
Poverty is a scourge to be combatted at the systemic level, and the time has come to act to enable the most vulnerable to escape their precariousness.

And we must, as policymakers at the European, national, and local levels, take the necessary steps to ensure their non-discriminatory access to housing, healthcare, justice, education, and a first job with a minimum income, perhaps indexed according to the poverty threshold of each member state.
Investing in the promotion of innovation and social experimentation, and in the reduction of poverty, will enable us to implement a strategy of sustainable, intelligent, and inclusive growth.
The Europe we desire and need currently is a Europe of solidarity.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would first like to congratulate the rapporteur, Ms. Levin, for her excellent work.

As rapporteur for the opinion of the Development Committee, I am pleased that the Fisheries Committee has taken up the elements contained in our opinion, as it is crucial that the development dimension
should be taken into account in measures aimed at combating illegal fishing at the global level, in the name of policy coherence and close alignment with development policy.
Indeed, combating illegal fishing requires global solutions and the implementation of measures by all States, including developing ones.
However, it is necessary that the technical and financial capabilities of States are also taken into account in the actions to be carried out.
Indeed, one cannot impose the same constraints, without supporting measures, on developed or developing countries.
Small island states, for example, have very limited capacities.
Therefore, it is necessary to support them in their efforts to combat illegal fishing.
And that is why the Union must strengthen the financial envelope in favour of the fisheries sector when it concludes agreements in this area with developing countries.

Furthermore, it is crucial that measures to combat illegal fishing are enforced, as this practice undermines the development of countries to the extent that it reduces the financial resources they could derive from the economic activity of fishing.
Alternatively, these resources are necessary for developing countries to implement social, economic, and educational policies.

Finally, it is important that the European Union, when implementing its measures to combat illegal fishing, promote the involvement of civil society and businesses alongside beneficiary states in developing countries.
Adopting a holistic approach is necessary to curb this scourge that is illegal fishing. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to state that, largely thanks to these outermost regions, the European Union is the world's leading maritime power.
This represents a major asset for Europe. Furthermore, the development and implementation of a comprehensive policy concerning the sea, oceans, and seabed are essential for the future.
But I fear that with 20 or 50 million euros, it may not be sufficient to undertake this major challenge.

The fight against illegal fishing is part of this broader policy, and it is urgently necessary at the European level to find an adequate solution to this problem, particularly within the framework of international cooperation.
I also note that the maritime zones of Guadeloupe, French Guiana, Martinique, Mayotte, and Réunion are regularly violated and plundered.
As the report does not mention it, I seize this opportunity to draw the attention of my colleagues and the Commission to this particular issue.
Thank you, Madam President. I wished first to acknowledge the Polish presidency, which demonstrated dynamism and determination.
Next week at the Council, our Heads of State and Government will have to make essential decisions for the future of the euro area, for the future of the Union.
They will also have to seriously address the recovery of growth.

That being said, we can clearly see that today, financial stability has become the priority of priorities and that the pressures, the tensions exerted from outside the Eurozone, but also within the Eurozone, are undermining our credibility, eroding confidence.
And in order to hope for the return of confidence, it is necessary to restore financial stability, to halt the alarming progression of national deficits and sovereign debt.
Financial stability has truly become the priority of priorities, it has become an urgent obligation for all.

Our democracies have, moreover, all embarked on very bold programs of cleaning up their public finances and reducing their debts. But financial stability is also a prerequisite for any resumption of growth.
but who speaks of solidarity, who speaks of financial stability, budgetary discipline – because these things go hand in hand, of course – must also speak of solidarity.
It seems important to us to ensure this dual movement of financial stability, budgetary discipline, and solidarity.
A final word on democracy.
Be careful not to disempower our democratic institutions.

Rather than considering recourse to a judicial mechanism to sanction in the event of budgetary drift, I would suggest we consider mechanisms of control and sanctions exercised by democratic institutions.

To be perfectly frank, I am not the spokesperson for the French Minister for Foreign Affairs. And very frankly, even though I belong to the same political affiliation as him, I am not, I would say, constantly in a position to relay the statements of the French Minister for Foreign Affairs.
To be entirely frank once again, I am not aware of any recent statements by Alain Juppé to that effect.

I simply believe that France's current position is to continually reaffirm that the euro is truly the heart of our European construction, that safeguarding the euro means that the euro is the heart of our European construction.

to affirm the preservation of this shared project and the preservation of the European Union. And that within this movement to safeguard the euro, we must of course consider the future, consider the protection of future generations, and the preservation of peace on our continent.
Thank you, Mr. President. Dear colleagues, tomorrow, we will vote for the third time on the new cooperation instrument.
developments that prompted support measures in the banana sector for ACP banana-exporting countries, following the reduction of their tariff preference, the BAM.

I have returned from Togo, where the 22nd session of the ACP-EU JPA took place. I believe I can tell you that our ACP partners are counting on us given the urgency of the situation.
The funds should have been released two years ago.
We must be aware of the lamentable consequences for our ACP partners if the ICD-BAM were to be rejected.
The situation of some farmers is dramatic. We can no longer wait and must act accordingly.
I therefore count on you to support the text. I thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President, dear colleagues. Our coordinator, Thijs Bergman, is ultimately unable to be present this evening due to personal reasons.
However, I know that he fully shares my analysis of this case.

Reaching a compromise on this legislative package proved lengthy and arduous, and while the outcome regarding human rights instruments and ICAI+, is satisfactory, we remain far from achieving our goals concerning the banana instrument.

Thus, the agreement reached on this text dismisses with a wave of the hand the mandate given to our negotiating team, which was to place Parliament on an equal footing with the Council on all programming decisions concerning the selection of strategic priorities and financial allocations.
For it is indeed the powers of our Assembly and the very spirit of the Treaty of Lisbon that are at issue here.
The selection of programming priorities is a highly political decision in which our Assembly must have its say.
By categorically refusing to acknowledge any power of oversight vested in Parliament and resorting to shameful blackmail, the Council has once again displayed a deplorable ideological retreat.
But Member States must understand that the European Union's external action is now a shared competence between our institutions.
That is why our Parliament must remain sovereign and reject the proposal under a banal instrument.
It is the only way we have to show the Council and the Commission that Parliament desires greater transparency in Community decisions.
If we lose this battle, the absurd would dictate that we must wait for a new treaty to finally obtain the powers already provided for in the Treaty of Lisbon.
At the risk of shocking the most federalist among you, I believe that defense policy is an eminently national policy.
It addresses the strategic, diplomatic, and security needs specific to each nation.
Capability sharing is nothing other than a relinquishment of sovereignty. The single market for military equipment is a vast joke. When certain Member States, believing that their
The defense ministry assures itself in Washington of equipping itself primarily with American matériel, Europe being incapable, in this domain as in so many others, of imposing community preference.
Regarding the common security challenges facing the Union's member states, there is nothing that cannot be resolved through intergovernmental cooperation, outside of any intervention from Brussels.

And I am sorry to say, but entrusting these areas to Ms. Ashton would amount to acknowledging that Moody's and Standard & Poor's have legitimacy in judging our economic policies, to accepting that the Mercosur partnership can impose on 27 peoples a purely German Europe, a pure mental aberration.

For 30 years, and even more so since the disappearance of the Soviet threat, defense budgets are the first to be sacrificed on the altar of budgetary rigor to the point of rendering most of our military assets

deficient or outdated, and this in the name of purely financial considerations, each awaiting from the neighbor or the supposed big brother America the efforts it is no longer prepared to make itself.
But you are mistaken in your approach.

It is only by returning to independent and resolute national policies that we can individually equip ourselves with the necessary means, not only for our security and national interests, but also for the cooperation of those means to address common challenges.
An accumulation of weaknesses and shortcomings has never constituted a strength.

Thank you, Mr. President. I wanted to express my support for the French position of the PPE group regarding the Treaty on Stability, Coordination and Economic Governance in Europe and its endorsement of the main conclusions reached by the Council.
Let us not be deceived.
This treaty represents a significant step toward greater economic and budgetary integration, toward greater financial stability.
Let us say it again here.
There can be no sustainable recovery of growth and employment without sound public finances.

but a treaty, that is to say, a set of rules and mutual commitments, can foster trust and accountability.

And as the president of the Socialist group saw fit to introduce partisan politics into this chamber, and by alluding to the upcoming French presidential campaign, evoking the Socialist candidate in that French presidential election, I wanted to respond.

Renegotiate what and with whom?
These words are entirely irresponsible.

Madame Ashton, good morning. Madagascar is one of the world’s poorest countries and is experiencing a political crisis whose resolution will depend on the implementation of the roadmap leading to presidential and legislative elections.
The growth of this country is negative.
Under normal circumstances, our contribution approximates 50% of this country’s budget.
The European Union has rightly suspended its budgetary support for the priorities of the 9th and 10th FED, but not for the SDGs.
Meanwhile, the population suffers, and businesses established in Madagascar are sometimes compelled to contribute against their will.

While supporting your stance, we wish you would exert all your influence with the Southern African Development Community (SADC) to ensure that the legal and judicial impasse regarding the return of the former president is resolved as soon as possible, as it represents one of the most sensitive aspects of the implementation of this roadmap.

I would appreciate your opinion on this matter and would also like to inform you that the European Union-Madagascar friendship group that we have recently established in the European Parliament is available to work with you and the Commission in the interest of the Malagasy people and in the defense of our Union’s values.

Mr. President, dear colleague, I would like to commend the rapporteur, Mr. Iturguise, for the quality of his work, for the lengthy negotiation process he had to conduct, and for the patience he demonstrated.

We are finally arriving at the vote on this report, which is extremely important because it allows us to bring to this hemicycle, to the Commission and the Council, the difficulties and concerns of our fellow citizens.
Here is further proof, if any were needed, of the effectiveness of the right to petition in Europe.
Petitions regarding the environment are predominant, and waste constitutes a significant concern for our fellow citizens.
This topic must address a societal problem.
We consume at a relentless pace.
We are only now beginning to realize that what is not consumed is thrown away.
This awareness must be absolutely reinforced among citizens, that is clear.
but this report is also a wake-up call for Member States.
It is still worrying to see that the states appear not to be controlling the situation.
Only six Member States transposed the Waste Framework Directive on time.
The number of complaints received on the matter sometimes demonstrates a lack of transparency in the selection of landfill sites.
Finally, and this is the most troubling aspect, organized crime appears to be acting with impunity.
A market of 75 billion euros inevitably attracts covetous attention.
States must send a strong signal.
It is necessary to increase sanctions against companies that disclose public contracts in order to enrich themselves.
This report is a warning signal to the States, but the European Commission must also play its part and ensure the proper implementation of waste directives.
It is necessary to make this file visible but also credible.
If no one plays along, we will continue to waste time and money in verification and counter-verification procedures that risk lasting for years.
Let us heed the message of the petitioners and halt this waste more swiftly.
Commissioner, Mr. Rapporteur, I would first like to congratulate Mr. Nicholson for the courage he displayed before the Council and the Commission.
But despite this, I fear that what we have achieved will not allow for a balance between producers and industrialists.
This agreement reminds me of a familiar illusion, the one children tell of a paradise where vegetarian lions graze on grass alongside sheep.
I do not believe it for a second. Since 2003, Ms. Fischer-Bowl has done everything to ideologically dismantle dairy quotas.
In October 2009, the French Court of Auditors nonetheless recognized the effectiveness of these dairy quotas.

Alternatively, today we find ourselves in a situation that will be even more dramatic, and we see what is currently happening in Denmark, where the strongest farms, with increased production, are all facing bankruptcy due to a 40% drop in land prices.
Do we want that for the European level?
I say no; mastery of production with the participation of public authorities is required. Thank you.
Madam Commissioner, the data protection standards of third-country nations still differ considerably from European standards.
It is, however, our duty to ensure that our minimum European standards of protection, which we invoke, are respected and guaranteed to European citizens.
It is fundamental that personal data be processed fairly and collected for specific and legitimate purposes.

European citizens must be guaranteed the right of access to and rectification of personal data concerning them, as well as the ability to lodge a judicial appeal in the event of a violation of their rights.
It is necessary to act to allow European and international standards to coexist and resolve a potential legal conflict detrimental to European citizens.
European legislation alone is not sufficient.
It must articulate and coexist intelligently with international standards, as we cannot disavow our duties and commitments to European citizens.
This situation echoes other debates within this forum.
She reminds us of the relevance of projects such as the establishment of a European program for monitoring the financing of terrorism,

Such a system would allow us to have a tool that has proven its effectiveness in the United States, while fully respecting domestic law and, therefore, the personal data protection of European citizens.
European institutions must continue their commitment in this regard and fully uphold their protection standards. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. First of all, thank you to the rapporteurs for their work.

In response to the crisis, the European Union has spent over a year strengthening its economic governance to avoid macroeconomic imbalances and excessive budget deficits, threatening the European economy. However, this has not prevented social exclusion nor the rise in unemployment.
It is time, no, it is now urgent, that the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy become an absolute priority for the European Commission and for Member States within a growth perspective.

Each state will have to implement a national employment plan, which means emphasis should be placed on a variety of issues, such as training, retraining, microcredit, apprenticeships, paid internships, etc.

Or, and Commissioner Andor recalled just now, we have 23 million unemployed people in Europe, but also 23 million SMEs and 23 billion euros of European funds dedicated to employment that remain unutilized.
we could almost make a 23-23 strategy out of it.
And this is without accounting for the €60 billion in cohesion funds that remain unallocated.
In Denmark and the Netherlands, social initiatives have been implemented and have proven effective, based on flexi-security.
Let us draw inspiration from it.

This also means that our social policy as a whole must be more adapted, with social incentives more advantageous than those linked to unemployment and active support for all socially responsible businesses.
We had poverty reduction targets to achieve by 2020, but we already know they will not be met, due to the lack of strong and adequate measures taken by the Member States.

Our role as parliamentarians must therefore be exercised fully, and it is our responsibility to demand that the same energy devoted to implementing robust economic governance measures also be directed towards ambitious, effective, and binding social governance measures.
Thank you, Madam President. Undeniably, the cause of women owes much to Europe.
The principle of equality between men and women was already enshrined in the Treaty of Rome and has been repeatedly reaffirmed since in numerous treaties.
Gender equality is truly a fundamental value of our European project.
Consequently, Europe has consistently striven proactively for gender equality and the advancement of women.
Little by little, progress has been made.
Numerous legislative instruments have been adopted, implemented, and directives established.
Here, within our Parliament itself, there has for many years been an extremely active and vigilant commission on women's rights and gender equality.
A European institute for gender equality has been established.
Programs are implemented, and financial resources are approved year after year.
And more recently, on March 2nd, we had the opportunity to celebrate the second edition of European Equal Treatment Day, Equal Payers, focusing on equal treatment and equal pay.
A European equal payment day. Undeniably, the legislative arsenal exists. European resolve has materialized on several occasions.
However, it must be acknowledged that the struggle remains relevant, the struggle for equality between men and women and, in particular, for equal pay.
There is consistently an average gender pay gap of approximately 17% across all countries of the European Union.
For work of equal value, women still earn 17% less than men.
This is, of course, entirely unacceptable.
The Parliament’s Women’s Committee is currently working on a draft resolution calling on the European Commission to revise the 2006 directive on equality of…
which is one of the most concerning and central struggles, at the heart of the anxieties and demands of European women in all our societies.

On another subject, that of the introduction of quotas, quotas both within the decision-making bodies of large companies and within political life. I come from a country, France, which adopted them long ago, more than
outlining binding rules regarding quotas in political life, and more recently, approximately one year ago, a law establishing quotas on the boards of directors of large companies.
France is not the only country, of course, to have adopted such legislation.
So, what is the assessment? After several years of implementation in one case, a few months in the other, it must be acknowledged that things have shifted, that progress has been made.
Therefore, a necessary evil.
Quotas have an effect.

Madam Commissioner, you have recently taken a significant step towards establishing quotas at the European level within the decision-making bodies of large companies by launching this extensive public consultation aimed at gathering opinions on the actions to be implemented, and potentially legislative actions to be implemented.
On this matter, you will have my full and complete support. I thank you.

and then a question to the European Commission so that acts may allow us to address a number of our concerns related to the common agricultural policy.

we are aware of the stakes in terms of management, in terms of food safety,

Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would first like to thank Madame the Rapporteur and our assistants for the work accomplished.
This report now aptly bears its name, namely, removing obstacles to citizenship.
Europe is a remarkable project, but it is too frequently observed that it is not yet perfectly defined.
Let us take the economic crisis as an example.
It has brought to light our weaknesses and enabled us to build more robustly the regulatory institutions of our single market.
For the European citizen, it’s the same.
The petitions committee, a veritable complaints office, records the grievances of our fellow citizens every day.

Despite all our policies that advocate for mobility, adherence to European values, and exchange, there remain far too many obstacles to the exercise of citizenship.

With my PPE colleagues, we have made a great many proposals, the most numerous, and I wish to thank them for this.
It is a report that must produce a sense of belonging and European identity, which it is our task to recreate and maintain through these measures.
Our Europe must be a Europe that protects.
Commissioner Viviane Reding put forward 25 very concrete proposals in favor of citizens.
