citizen participation, healthcare abroad, town twinning, minority rights, etc. We still find it difficult to fully leverage the capabilities offered by Europe.
Rights are exercised, claims are heard.
We are the conduits for this here.
The European Year of Citizenship in 2013 must demonstrate to citizens that, with free movement, there is also free use of rights in Europe.
I believe that taxation is an interesting tool for influencing behavior.

I believe that energy consumption should align with a price signal indicative for the consumer and, above all, I think that in order to avoid any distortion on the internal market, we must strive to harmonize our tax practices.
The principle of proportionality in the various levels of taxation of energy products therefore appears to me to be a necessity.
And in the case we are considering, for example, this would allow us to put an end to the diesel tourism we are currently witnessing, which is not an acceptable situation.
I therefore share the philosophy of the Commission’s draft directive revision proposal.

Nevertheless, if we are to achieve our objectives in terms of CO2 emission reduction or energy efficiency, it is also necessary that our collective decisions do not penalize citizens or sectors particularly vulnerable to the

prices on global markets and I am thinking of the agricultural sector, for example. The proposed directive will certainly have a differentiated impact depending on the taxation level of each member state, but an impact nonetheless on the price of diesel.
The question is who, in the final, will have to bear this price increase?
Are there genuinely viable, realistic, and accessible alternatives for consumers?
As a fictional rapporteur on the environment committee, I advocate for an ambitious yet, above all, sustainable position for all.

I therefore advocate for greater progressivity and the entry into force of the proposal and its principle of proportionality by 2030, subject to a new impact study, updating that on which the Commission’s decision was based and which was nonetheless conducted five years ago.

I, rather, here and now, we had a debate concerning the wave of layoffs in Europe resulting from the economic crisis, particularly at Arcelor, a multinational corporation present in 9 European member states and which is restructuring its production facilities in Europe in response to a stagnant demand for steel.
Since the shutdown of two blast furnaces in Belgium, in Luxembourg, and the idling of a blast furnace in France, it is estimated that nearly 6000 direct jobs would be threatened in 2012.

Beyond unacceptable practices such as stop-and-go, a practice that should be better regulated, lies the broader question of European steelmaking and adaptation to change, which demands extremely urgent responses.

Six months ago, the Commission announced the need to conduct, in the wake of the economic crisis, a new consultation exercise for the responsible management of restructurings with social partners and public authorities.
My question is simple: 6 months later, where do we stand?

Thank you, Mr. President, Madam the Commissioner, dear colleagues. I first wish to refute the unfounded allegations concerning the circulation in France of 500,000 to 1 million counterfeit biometric passports purportedly circulating in our country.
France takes the risks of identity fraud very seriously.
She does not take material offenses lightly.
At the initiative of its government, identity theft is a criminal offense punishable by one year of imprisonment and a fine of €15,000.
The conditions for issuing identity documents have been simplified, which has enabled prefectures to free up additional resources to combat this fraud.
Thus, in each prefecture, a fraud reference point is designated.
Furthermore, the security measures governing the issuance of identity documents have been strengthened.
For example, civil registry data provided may be verified between administrative services, to the greatest extent possible by electronic means, in order to limit the risks of forgery.
Some birth certificates are also issued on secure paper.
The same strictness applies to proof of domicile documents.
The Ministry of the Interior has committed to increasing the security of proof-of-address documents with the inclusion of a barcode.

The standard processing of a title application includes authorized consultation of relevant files, comparison of all documents submitted in previous title applications, and potential authentication of supporting documentation.

The security of title issuance is further ensured by the applicant’s dual appearance, first at the time of application submission and then for title collection, as well as the taking of two fingerprints.
And this is without mentioning the enhanced verification procedures for the renewal of lost and stolen titles, for comparative purposes with the data held by the prefectures.

Furthermore, France informs international cooperation bodies, and notably Interpol, that I am nearing the conclusion, Mr. President, I have almost finished, of the list of passports issued or lost and stolen, so that they are not used for fraudulent purposes.
My dear colleagues, France, like the rest of the European Union, is committed
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, first of all, an observation. Our citizens increasingly wish to find and consume food produced locally and seasonally, notably for reasons of health and quality.
We must find ways to enable farmers to respond effectively and rapidly to this growing demand.

We must support the establishment of local infrastructure for producers, such as maintaining local abattoirs, which, while ensuring rigorous sanitary controls, allow for the development of short local supply chains and the strengthening of direct sales.
Support for local agriculture and direct sales should help producers market their products and make them known to consumers.
Strengthening these direct relationships will enable farmers to retain a larger share of the added value generated on their holdings.

It is necessary to encourage and facilitate direct sales within the farm and to support collective actions by farmers who wish to open collective sales outlets, allowing local consumers access to a wider range of products.

The European Commission must facilitate the emergence, sustainability, and development of direct-to-consumer delivery sales systems, such as AMAPs in France, which allow nearly 3,000 farmers to supply 60,000 families.

Finally, Member States must be able to add further criteria concerning, in particular, the size of the holding, the volume of production, or the traditional character of the product to define local agriculture. Thank you.

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. I welcome the fact that this corrective budget concerning the financing of ITER, which was approved by a large majority in the Budget Committee on 29 March last,
By financing this additional cost, we avoid dismissing a strategic project of fundamental research in which the European Union plays a leading role, and we honor our international commitments.
Let us recall that none of the seven Euratom community partners has questioned its overall contribution to the project.
Japan, despite the Fukushima disaster, has decided to rigorously uphold its budgetary commitments to ITER.
Without this agreement, hundreds of researchers would have had to suspend their work, and the ITER project would have experienced detrimental delays.
Today, a thousand people work on ITER’s disruption mitigation activities.
From 2015 through 2017-2018, the construction of buildings and assembly of the machine could mobilize up to 4,000-5,000 people at this site.
To conclude, Mr. President, ITER is a source of pride for Europe and a symbol of our excellence.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Rapporteur, thank you for the work we have accomplished together.
The European Union needs a manifesto, a shared political vision on the major environmental challenges facing it by 2020 and beyond.
That is precisely the utility of launching a seventh action program for the environment by synergizing existing financial frameworks and mobilizing new funding resources.
This program must ensure coherence and articulation between the European Union's environmental strategies and sectoral policies, whether concerning agriculture,
Fishing, research and innovation, health, transportation, regional development, land use planning, and urban policies, of course.
Despite the economic crisis undermining the European Union, we must not succumb to a short-term vision and abandon all ambition in the environmental and climate sphere.
Inaction would be fatal.
The stakes are too high, particularly with regard to the efficient use of our resources and the enhancement of natural capital.
We must therefore resolutely invest in the sustainable economy and eco-innovation, a source of growth, competitiveness, and employment.
It is our responsibility to promote eco-design, recycling, but also environmental labeling of products in order to avoid waste and poor consumption choices.
We cannot overlook this environmental education that is essential for European citizens.
The environmental action program is a policy planning instrument, but it is also a communication tool.

It must provide the necessary readability and predictability for national and local administrations, citizens, but also for entrepreneurs and investors regarding the European Union’s environmental choices.
European regulation should not become a punishment or a shackle.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, in the face of the profound transformations our world is subject to today, the EU must reform its Generalized Preference System.
As with any compromise, this one does not deviate from the rule.
While satisfactory from a purely commercial standpoint, it is far from perfect. For we must bear in mind that this regulation is addressed to developing countries.
In developing its new differentiation paradigm, the Commission states its intention to refocus its action in favor of the poorest countries,
It does not appear entirely sustainable at first glance.
To this end, however, the Commission developed a strictly accounting-based vision, based solely on the criterion of GDP per capita.
One can clearly see the limitation of this approach.
What about the numerous middle-income developing countries with undiversified economies and vulnerability to climate shocks?
The agreement reached with the Council does not address this issue, and that is why I urge colleagues to vote in favor of the three amendments that will be submitted on this text.
Sir Commissioner, the issue of the availability of public consultations within the various plans of the European Union is not new, unfortunately.

It is, in my view, a crucial question. To that end, I have already not only posed several written questions to the European Commission since 2008, but I have also personally questioned Mr. Barroso in writing.

Indeed, the Commission must comply with the principle of equal access to information for all European citizens, as recalled by the Court of First Instance of the European Communities in its judgment of 20 November 2008.
I was not at all satisfied with the European Commission’s response, according to which public consultations do not purport to provide a fully representative picture of all opinions.
According to this response, the Commission acknowledges that certain positions and viewpoints may be overrepresented to the detriment of others.
This is not an answer.
I question the criteria that would allow for the measurement of an overrepresentation of the European population.
If written consultations are not overrepresented due solely to availability in English, for example, they fail to consult European citizens.
Thus, the result provides a misleading indication and should therefore not be used by the European Commission.
If we want to preserve written consultations as a foundation for the European Commission’s legislative proposals, we must guarantee democratic, transparent, and equitable security for all citizens.
Thus, if the European Commission opts for written consultation, it must assume its responsibilities and ensure the necessary resources for multilingualism and the translation of questionnaires.
To conclude, I would like to add that multilingualism is not the only obstacle.

It would also be necessary to integrate into the analysis excessively short deadlines for submissions, as well as the limited resources allocated by the Commission to communicate about these consultations, which are unfortunately accessible primarily to those in the know. Thank you.
The proposed regulations aim to grant the European Commission enhanced powers to control national budgets and economic policies.
The rules will be stricter, and defaulting states will be subjected by Brussels’ technocrats to budget cuts and structural reforms in order to restore their financial equilibria.
This enhanced monitoring is referred to as guardianship.
States will be penalized, fined, let us say, sanctioned—financial sanctions will be strengthened and more automatic.
Even if certain amendments aim to prevent austerity measures alone through growth initiatives, your proposals serve only to sweeten the pill.
Growth, as you know as well as I do, is not decreed.
Without consulting the people and with the complicity of Brussels, we permanently lose our budgetary sovereignty, our freedom to choose our policies.

And as, little by little, according to the technique of the Chinese thief, the European bureaucratic, technocratic, and totalitarian state has finished constituting itself, we will have lost our freedom as a people altogether.

Thank you, Mr. President. Without diminishing the importance of the economic choices we must assume, you will allow me to emphasize a remark of a more political nature within the context of this debate?
Over recent weeks, we have once again seen evidence of the double-speak of certain European leaders, or those who consider themselves to be so.
As everyone continues to advocate for economic, budgetary, and fiscal policies that are finally worthy of the name, and as this demand even appears as a sincere condition,
a prerequisite for the survival of the eurozone, and yet, once comfortably ensconced, these gentlemen deem it clever to denigrate the balanced recommendations emanating from
the Commission to free itself from certain commitments or, in the worst case, to turn public opinion against these "decrees from Brussels," as it is said.
This irresponsible attitude might be laughable were we not in such a tragic situation.
I state this plainly: our debates concerning stability, the necessary consolidation of public finances, or the efforts to be undertaken in terms of growth are indeed devoted to economics.
if past missteps regarding public debt and deficits do not cease, and if governments of the Member States persist in their ill-fated course.
We are playing with fire at the moment.
European rules must apply to everyone, without exception, even for the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg.
It requires a minimum of courage, and our public opinions are ready for it, far more so than some of their leaders would believe.
And a final word to Madame Goulard, or else I’ll have to show her the corporate credit card. I would say, to conclude, to Madame Goulard, in *Redemption*, there is Racha.

Thank you, Mr. President. I would first like to commend the determination of the European Commission, and particularly your own, Mr. Commissioner, for consistently placing the recovery and deepening of the single market at the top of the European agenda.

You recalled, Commissioner, that for over two years now, both the Commission and the European Parliament have been working to identify the missing links in the single market, to identify the challenges and sectors for which more single market integration is needed. More single market integration for more growth, more competitiveness, more jobs.

The European Council, for its part, also eventually conveyed the full importance it attached to the rapid and effective implementation of the twelve priority proposals for the single market, the twelve drivers for growth.
And rather than constantly seeking to invent new instruments of growth, we would be well-advised to work with the toolkit we already possess.

We therefore seize the opportunity of the resolution that will be submitted to the vote of our Assembly tomorrow to send a strong political message to the Member States. Greater speed and efficiency in the transposition of directives already agreed.
Increased mobilization and engagement in newly opened construction sites. I will cite only one example: the strengthening of worker mobility. Easier movement, smoother traffic flow.
We shall welcome with great interest, Mr. Commissioner, the second stage of the act for the single market that you will present after the summer.
We will demonstrate both political will and the ability to put pressure on Member States. Thank you.
We experienced the Mediator scandal some time ago.
We now have the scandal of breast implants, which unfortunately highlights, as you said, Mr. Commissioner, the shortcomings of European health safety.
This breast implant scandal, these 14 years of fraud from 1996-2010, unpunished.
These are 500,000 prostheses used worldwide, 8,000 implant removals, and 48 confirmed cases of cancer.
It is now 3500 complaints filed. This figure is alarming, shocking.

How, despite the warnings from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, FDA, Commissioner, and the number of complaints and convictions for prosthetic device failure filed in Great Britain and France, in particular, how could the national and European agencies have overlooked such a fraud?
This tragedy immediately led us to consider improving the European system for medical device control, as you have just explained.
We must, sir Commissioner, build a new system today capable of preventing scandal. But it is a new system that must be built.
It is announced for the autumn, as you indicated, this new legislation.
As a co-drafter of this resolution, I am naturally pleased.
But, Commissioner, you seem to wish to take into account a significant portion of our concerns as outlined in this resolution.
So, why make an unacceptable exception for so many parliamentarians present here?
Why not want the creation of a market authorization for class 3 medical devices, the highest risk class?
Mr. Commissioner Dali, could you explain your position to me?
Mr. President, we are currently experiencing a situation with an increase in production of over 2.5%. Simultaneously, industrialists are lowering prices.
In Italy, in Germany, in England, and throughout Europe, prices are falling.
This clearly indicates that prices are linked to production volume, and we must organize both production volumes and prices simultaneously.
At the same time, today, producers are experiencing an increase of over 44% in vegetable proteins and 30% in the price of cereals.
Parliament has already voted on the necessity here of ensuring that capital gains are shared between producers and that farmers are not victims of companies and large retailers.

Therefore, I am asking the Commission today, but also the Council, to reconsider the undermining of production control. But at the same time, I am stating very clearly that Member States must clean up their own houses, because there are countries that have respected the rules of quotas and others that have not.
And that, too, is what led to these quotas being questioned.
Therefore, there is a dual responsibility, the Commission and the Member States.
Gentlemen, esteemed colleagues, a unique European railway space—this is a fine European integration policy.
Here is a fine policy wherein European construction is at the heart of the daily concerns of Europeans.

Too often disparaged, because it was faltering, Europe finally, with this directive, shows the way towards a major policy of sustainable transport and opens the field for a major railway investment policy for employment.

I welcome the principal measures taken in the organization of the rail network, the establishment of national regulators in each Member State, and the creation of a five-year multiannual investment framework, thereby stipulating the organization's funding commitments.

rail infrastructures, but also, I welcomed the establishment of financial flow transparency between managers and operators within the framework of integrated companies. The reminder concerning non-discriminatory access to certain

Finally, I welcome the confirmation sought by the Members of the European Parliament of certain guarantees, particularly on the social front. For example, the absence of a reference to minimum service levels, as well as the complete separation between the General Electricity and Gas National Network (GECNR) and the operator.

but allow me to mention a requirement that we must cease to consider, particularly on the part of the European Commission, the liberalization of the railway sector as the sole strategic horizon for the development of a single railway area; let us instead decide on an integrated European investment strategy conducive to employment in Europe.
Also, I would like, to conclude, to ask you a question, Mr. Callas.
Three days after the European Council of June 28 and 29, following the endorsement of a €120 billion growth pact to revitalize the European economy,
notably through investment in infrastructure. Could you indicate to us, Mr. Commissioner, what sum the European railway sector is likely to benefit from within the framework of this growth pact?
Madam President, we will have a debate on ACTA tomorrow, but I would like to address a question this evening that is admittedly tangential, yet extremely important regarding this matter.
These are the remarks that Commissioner Mr. De Guth made in the International Trade Committee on Wednesday, June 20th.

I tell you this: if you decide on a negative vote before the European Court rules, let me tell you that the Commission will nevertheless continue to pursue the current procedure before the Court of Justice.
We are committed to it.
A negative vote will not halt the proceedings before the Court of Justice.

Not only do these statements appear to disregard the treaties, but above all, and this is what I want to denounce, they demonstrate an unacceptable contempt for the European Parliament, for democracy in general, and for the citizens we represent.
Here, at a time when European citizens, as a whole,
Thank you, Mr. President.
Sir Commissioner, for my part, I would like to thank you very warmly.
Thanks to your persistence, your procedural maneuvers, you allow us to demonstrate the importance of the European Parliament as a co-legislature.
Thank you, Commissioner, for having spurred hundreds of thousands of citizens to take to the streets and 2.8 million to sign petitions.
They discovered that democracy is at stake here, that European elected officials are representatives of the people, their representatives.
Thank you again to the millions of internet users who followed the debates and votes in committee and who continue to follow us today.
I greet them. It is a breath of fresh air in our institutions, too often perceived as technocratic.
Thank you, Commissioner, but in a democracy, there is also another principle.
It is the fundamental principle, that of responsibility.
Tomorrow, we will take responsibility, and I would also like to thank you tomorrow for accepting your responsibility, your failure, the failure of your work method.
President, dear colleagues, I speak on behalf of Maurice Pongard, rapporteur for the opinion of the Development Committee on the report by Mr. Gallagher.
It seemed important to me to recall that the European Union, when it wishes to sanction a country practicing unsustainable fishing, must take its level of development into account.

Indeed, in the name of the principle of policy coherence with development objectives, it is crucial, in my view, that measures adopted in the area of fisheries do not undermine the development plans and strategies put in place by the European Union in these countries.
Mr. Gallagher’s draft report takes up this important idea for our development committee by stipulating that measures should neither be unjustified nor discriminatory.

I therefore invite the European Commission, when adopting such measures, to respect this principle of policy coherence with development objectives and to duly take into account the level of development and the vulnerability of the countries concerned. Thank you.
This third reform of the common fisheries policy must not once again be carried out against the interests of fishermen.

No, not all fishermen are these plunderers of the sea, solely responsible for the poor health of fish stocks, as claimed, by encompassing all categories of fishing, by environmental organizations and the European Commission.

It is, of course, understood that fish stocks must be preserved, but it is also necessary to allow our fishermen to live from their activity and to preserve the economic fabric, the dynamism, and the cultural identity of our coastal regions.
Or the European executive’s main measures will once again move in the direction of reducing the number of fishermen to achieve the mythical maximum sustainable yield.
I would like to remind you that the French fleet has decreased by over 50% since 1980.

The Commission proposes, in particular, the implementation of transferable individual quotas, a guarantee of industrialization and concentration within the sector, or alternatively, the total prohibition of discharges which professionals consider unrealistic.
This reform project likely suits the industrial fleet, but as it stands, it would mean the programmed death of what remains of local and artisanal fishing.

Thank you, Mr. President, Commissioner. I would like to congratulate the EPP rapporteur, our colleague Ms. Karins, on this difficult report, considering the sensitive nature of bilateral negotiations in the energy field between European countries and third states.
The agreement reached in trilogue negotiations will allow for the swift implementation of the Commission’s draft decision, and pragmatically speaking, there is good reason to welcome this.
Europe’s energy sector is advancing, certainly not quickly enough, but it is advancing.
A significant energy importer, the European Union is structurally dependent on certain supplier countries.

To foster a more European perspective on our energy strategy, it had become necessary to disseminate more widely within the European Commission information concerning energy agreements, while respecting the principle of subsidiarity.
The establishment of an information mechanism regarding intergovernmental agreements will therefore enhance transparency in the energy market and thus enable anticipation of energy supply issues.
I am pleased that the present decision does not create an obligation regarding agreements between commercial companies.

In times of crisis and considering issues related to competition and competitiveness, we had a duty to protect the interests of our companies and the rules governing the protection of private contracts.
Thank you, Mr. President, esteemed colleagues. I would like to thank our two rapporteurs for the work they have done on this file.

It was necessary because we were starting from a very distant point with the Commission’s basic proposal. No specific mention of the outermost regions, directly concerned by competition from Latin American countries. No automatic triggering.

of the stabilization mechanism, no possibility offered to our Assembly of requesting the opening of a safeguard investigation, no consideration of social and environmental standards as potentially constituting a fair and competitive advantage.
That is why it is extremely important that tomorrow’s vote confirms the progress achieved on these points within the international trade committee.
Despite everything, this is not sufficient, as we know that the trigger thresholds for these two regulations are so high that they render these mechanisms practically inapplicable.
Furthermore, the Commission must provide an additional financial allocation to support the competitiveness of Community banana production.
Let us bear in mind that numerous jobs are at stake in these European regions, which already have record unemployment rates.
Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would first like to thank Charles Gorenz for his excellent report.
We all know here that the European Union provides more than half of the world’s total of official development assistance, and yet, as the MDG deadline approaches in 2015, even if some objectives seem
reached, we must ask ourselves how to improve our assistance, to make it more consistent with our trade policy, our agricultural policy, and our foreign policy.
The future of European development policy must rest on firm, measurable commitments with a short- and medium-term timeline.

The economic crisis, climate change, the rise of emerging powers, and land grabbing compel us to define new priorities. Priority must be given to ensuring food security, access to energy resources, and access to healthcare.

Certainly, a European consensus exists, but we must rethink European and international institutional systems concerning environmental and social matters, drawing inspiration from organizations that function effectively on a decision-making level, such as the WTO, for example.
Finally, and above all, we must explain to our fellow citizens that the development of third-world countries is not solely charity and solidarity, but also a source of development for ourselves.
One need only look at the markets opening up for Europeans in emerging countries, China, Brazil, and India.
2015 will also provide an opportunity to better account for the geostrategic developments of recent years, as the emerging nations of today were, until recently, still developing countries.
From now on, as undeniable economic powers, these countries must also contribute to international aid.
The European Union must be the promoter of responsible development aid at both the European and international levels.

The year 2015 will be more than a deadline; it will be a unique opportunity to rethink development aid, not as mere financial assistance, but as support for responsible development projects, both socially and environmentally.

I therefore join here with my colleagues from the other groups and with those from the Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions in requesting that 2015 be designated the European Year of Development and, above all, of responsible development.

Thank you, Mr. President. The agenda for change proposed by the Commission, in my opinion, raises numerous questions, the primary one being the concrete implementation of the principle of differentiation.

The Commission wishes that, starting in 2014, the selection of countries in which the European Union will invest its development aid will be based on the mechanical application of the sole criterion of per capita income.
Or, as Ms. Ashton has recalled, these questions are not solely of an accounting nature, but merit a genuine political debate concerning the definition of our priorities in international cooperation.
Furthermore, this differentiated approach, in my view, does not align with the spirit of the Cotonou Agreement.

I am convinced that ACP countries that have achieved positive economic performance should be encouraged in their transition towards more sustainable growth. These countries should not be unduly penalized for having succeeded in ensuring growth through discipline, good governance, and prudent economic policies.
Madam President, Commissioner, let us acknowledge the initiative taken by Jacques Delors 20 years ago, at the very moment the Berlin Wall was falling.

And yet, despite all these advancements we have observed since the beginning of our debate, it must be acknowledged that the Single Act is now synonymous with injustice, inequality, and economic liberalism.
Therefore, I would like to hear from you, Mr. Barnier, Commissioner, to tell us how we will build together a more equitable Europe, a facilitating Europe, a protective Europe.

And there are a number of avenues, and I would like to hear your thoughts on these avenues, which lie at the heart of the economic and social crisis as, unfortunately, we know it: tax harmonization, public services,
protective, minimum wage in Europe, establishment of strengthened cooperation, job-creating, facilitate cross-border cooperation and develop a policy of fair exchange.
Here are, I believe, the challenges that lie before us, 20 years later.
And I am counting on you, Commissioner, to ensure that we jointly champion this fine policy of European construction.

Thank you, Mr. President. As a member of the Internal Market and Consumer Protection Committee, I have closely followed the report by my colleague Regina Bastos concerning the 20 main concerns of citizens and businesses.
We debated this report, which is also connected to our discussion on the 20th anniversary of the single market.
Twenty years already, that the free movement of goods, people, services, and capital is supposed to be able to fully operate within our living space, exchange area, internal market.

I was particularly interested in the fact that at the forefront of the concerns expressed by our European fellow citizens are the licensing of professional qualifications and that we must truly be particularly proactive and particularly effective.

This is what our citizens expect in order to truly implement, in the very near future, procedures for the recognition of their credentials, their skills, and their professional qualifications that are genuinely faster, simpler, more efficient, and less costly.
It is a genuine challenge.

As a fictitious rapporteur for the PPE Group on this subject, the modernization of these procedures, I am actively working with the other members of the IMCO Committee to genuinely address this major challenge of mobility.
Greater mobility for a greater Europe. That is what our citizens are calling for. Thank you.
The Committee on Petitions has this year acquired the right to be automatically associated with the hearings of European citizens' initiatives.
It is for me the strong signal of the year 2011 for this commission.
Citizens already had a commission to which they could turn in the event of a violation of their rights, but this is now also the case when they have proposals to improve European legislation.
I wish that the Committee on Petitions could thus be increasingly regarded as the preferred interlocutor of citizens within the European Parliament.
This issue of consideration is also reflected in the outcomes of the petitions committee’s decisions.
Too often, we are approached by citizens facing legal quagmires on which we would like to take a stance. But when the issues are European,
Solutions should be European; we remain powerless because subsidiarity still does not align with European solutions due to a lack of national will.

I will take the difficult example of transnational divorces. The problems are both national and European when custody or visitation rights extend beyond national borders, those of Germany, in this instance.
Despite the glaring difficulties experienced by many parents of children born of binational unions, we remain powerless to act in Parliament.

My proposal for all European citizens to have the right to a national ombudsman, particularly from Germany, which submits a vast number of petitions, modeled after the Defender of Rights in France, has had no effect whatsoever.
However, in the case of transnational divorces, this remains a problematic solution reconciling European law and national regulations.
In numerous cases, European law appears powerless to meet the expectations of citizens.
The European Year of Citizenship 2013 will need to address citizens’ grievances, the costs of forces, but we need means of action to be
